PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for post-graduate and second degree students will:

(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criteria for entry to such courses. The restricted availability of Commonwealth post-graduate scholarships and the difficulty of finding part-time work in employment related areas further restricts the ability of post-graduate students to pay tuition fees.

(ii) result in higher attrition rates in post-graduate and second degree studies. Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50% of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22% of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of Press reports at the weekend indicating that some of Australia's most wanted men-drug traffickers and other law-breakers on the run-have been slipping out of Australia by flying out of Port Macquarie and then island-hopping to freedom via Lord Howe and Norfolk Islands to New Zealand? —I am informed that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is aware of the article, which I have read as well. The information supplied by the Minister in answer to the question is as follows: The allegations in the article are false. —I think I have indicated to the Senate on an earlier occasion that, as a matter of normal practice, areas of policy are continually under review within my Department. I put the Children's Services Program under review jointly between my Department and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat. I asked Mr Spender, a member of this Parliament, to assist the officers in the process of that review. As a result, a document which has been somewhat lavishly termed the 'Spender report' came into existence. In fact, it was an internal departmental working document. It was not my intention to release it to the public. It is a document which does no more than form a basis for my giving policy matters consideration. The matters which are contained within the Spender recommendations from the Department and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat are matters which I am proposing to put before the Government for its consideration. I do not believe that the release of that internal document would in any way assist the area of concern that the honourable senator has mentioned. As far as the extraordinarily wide circulation is concerned, that is a matter which is no doubt far better known to the honourable senator than to me. My understanding is that the document has had a reasonably restricted circulation; but, if it has become wider than I am aware of, that would not be all that unusual, unfortunately.
—Then why not release it?

—In response to that interjection, let me say that I did give some consideration to releasing it because it had apparently been given a rather wider circulation than it was officially entitled to, but I see no reason why I should change my practices just because somebody chooses to release a report in a way which is not official.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAMAGE TO LOBSTER POTS: COMPENSATION CLAIM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, concerns a claim by a lobster fisherman from Western Australia against the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth in December 1979 for damage to lobster pots by a Royal Australian Navy vessel during naval exercises off the Lancelin naval gunfire support barge in 1979. It has been pointed out to me that the claim, which was for a few hundred dollars, has been refused, but not before nearly two years had elapsed. I ask the Attorney-General: Firstly, is it a fact that a time lapse of nearly two years did occur before this claim was refused? Secondly, if so, does the Attorney-General not think that the Department was tardy in dealing with this claim? Thirdly, as the amount involved in this claim is of little importance to the Crown but of great concern to the fisherman, and noting the disparity of interpretation that appears to exist between the Department of Defence and the Attorney-General's Department, will he sympathetically reconsider this claim? Fourthly, whether or not he agrees to this request, will he consult with the Minister for Defence so that the rules can be clearly conveyed to the fisherman?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the facts relating to the matter raised by Senator Thomas are as follows: The Executive Officer of the Western Australian branch of the Australian Fishing Industry Council made a claim on behalf of the fisherman mentioned by Senator Thomas to the naval officer commanding the Western Australian area. On 25 September 1979 the Deputy Crown Solicitor replied to the Executive Officer acknowledging receipt of the claim. That reply referred to the wide publicity that had been given to the gunnery exercise and to the prohibition of fishing in the area. It appeared that other fishermen had moved their equipment from the area but this fisherman had not done so. Further correspondence from the Council raised the question of whether there had been some undertaking in 1977 by naval officers to pay compensation or to permit equipment to remain.

ANSWER.PARA: The Deputy Crown Solicitor had no information on these matters and it was necessary to consult with the Royal Australian Navy and ultimately with the Department of Defence in Canberra. The matter has not yet been resolved. However, in September of this year the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth did write denying liability. That is the situation as it stands. Apparently there was some delay in correspondence passing between the Deputy Crown Solicitor and the Department of Defence in relation to the information that was being sought. That is the background to the matter. Senator Thomas asks me whether I will look at the matter again and consult with the Department of Defence. I will do so.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the continual concern of people living in the north and west of Queensland that sales tax is levied on the wholesale price of goods, plus freight, and that in some instances the sales tax is added after the retailer's mark-up. Will the Minister advise at what stage sales tax is imposed on goods and also, more importantly, whether the Commissioner of Taxation will send investigators to these areas to ensure that the law is not being incorrectly imposed, with the resultant extra charges being carried by the residents of remote areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have answered a number of similar questions on this matter. Perhaps I should state again that, in the case of goods sold by wholesale, sales tax is payable in respect of the selling price at the point of the last wholesale sale. This price generally reflects all costs incurred in getting the goods to the point of wholesale sale. To the extent that it reflects a component to cover freight, sales tax is payable on freight. The freight position is not peculiar to country traders but applies equally to all wholesalers who incur freight in getting goods to the point of wholesale sale. It is not uncommon for tax on the freight component to be eliminated for country traders by arranging for the wholesale sale to occur, for example, in a capital city where the goods are manufactured. Sales tax is imposed at the wholesale stage and is not payable on the retailer's mark-up or freight incurred after the wholesale sale.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the request relating to the Commissioner sending someone to see that the matter is dealt with properly, I am advised that the Commissioner's officers undertake regular audits of registered sales tax payers, including those in remote areas, to ensure that the provisions of the sales tax law are being properly applied. If Senator Collard has any instances in mind that he would like to have referred to the Treasurer, I will see that that is done. If there is any doubt in the minds of wholesalers as to how this matter should be dealt with, perhaps some clarification could be given if we could have more specific information on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Rundle shale project, similar to other shale projects throughout the world, has suffered delays and reassessments due to two things-technology and comparative oil prices. Those are matters which any mining or extraction venture throughout the world must confront. The fact is that the movement of shares in the Rundle project was at its heaviest in its decline in the period late last year prior, in fact, to the exposure of the differences between the partners. I remind the honourable senator of what happened.
—The differences between what you were saying and the truth.
—What happened was-and I remind the interjector, who is consistently totally inaccurate--
—Tell us about sending your Press secretary along to the Australian Financial Review to complain about its story. Come on, tell us about that.
—I suggest that, as that interjection may have been recorded, I could have it repeated. The habit of saying these things so that they can get into Hansard--
—I will repeat it. You sent your Press secretary along to the Australian Financial Review to complain about its story and then you denied it.

—Mr President, because that was said I want to say emphatically that I did no such thing. What is more, I said so in this Senate. I repeat: I did no such thing. The fact of the matter at Rundle is simply that the Rundle project started out between two co-partnerships, one of which involved the Esso company and the other was the Australian co-partnership. They set about their exploratory mining ventures and drilling and also the testing of their retorts.

ANSWER.PARA: When they did their drilling, at a given point of time they found that the material that lay between the shale strata was such that it was unstable and would not form a mining wall, that the angle of the mining wall would be such that they would not be able to recover as much of the shale as they had previously thought and as they had previously informed the public and that, therefore, there would be more left in the ground. They found that the material itself was so unstable when dry and in the air that it could not form a fill-in and would have to be disposed of elsewhere. Therefore, they found that there would have to be a complete reconsideration of the costing and the mining techniques and a complete re-evaluation by mining engineers. At the same time, they struck difficulties in the testing of the various kinds of retorts in America.

I remind the Senate that, when I discovered this, I and the Treasurer called upon the partners first of all to determine whether they did have differences of opinion. On finding that they did have differences of opinion and that those differences were not the same as the public understood, the Government, through the Treasurer and myself, called upon the Rundle partners to settle their differences as soon as possible, to find the facts and to expose them to the people of Australia. So, the facts on Rundle were exposed by the direct action of the Government and myself. The shares--

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't remember what you said a couple of months ago.

—The interjectors go on. This is factually what I said a couple of months ago and before that. The shares in Rundle were falling heavily before I visited Rundle. They had fallen very heavily before then. Presumably those who were close to the mining venture must have known of the technical and mining difficulties that they struck but anybody who knows the situation throughout the world in regard to shale oil at this moment knows that these difficulties are being located. The stabilising of crude oil prices in the world, with a decline in the real price of crude oil, has set back synthetics. The fact of the matter, therefore, is that the market value of the shares relates to the prospectivity of the project as determined by the shareholders and the share purchasers in the market. The market forces are operating.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware of any other mining projects of which investors in Queensland should also be wary?

—What an extraordinary situation this is. Against the backdrop of the Australian Labor Party suggesting that people had talked up or down the value of shares, now a Labor senator is asking a responsible Minister to give opinions on the value of shares in the share market. I have to say that, in the course of my time in this Parliament, I have never heard a more irresponsible question.

—Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate inform the Senate of the cost to the taxpayer of recalling Parliament should the Australian Democrats go ahead with the cynical exercise proposed by their Acting Leader on the Nationwide program last week? Is it true that the Australian Democrats said that they intended to withhold Government Supply in the form of the sales tax legislation for a period of three months but then promised that they would pass the Bills after that three months? The three months, of course, expires in January when the Parliament is in recess.

—The question relates to a Nationwide program last week in which I took part and in which I asserted that the Australian Democrats had said, upon making their first request, that if the House of Representatives refused that request and the legislation came back to the Senate they would pass it. My understanding is that the Democrats deny having said that. I have checked the media widely and it is clearly on record that that is what the Democrats said. Let there be no doubt about that at all. Any attempt now by the Democrats to make another request would be in absolute breach of what they have said publicly, quite clearly and unequivocally. The Democrats have now said that their intention is to have the Parliament recalled in some three months time. There are two questions there. If the Parliament were to be recalled, and I am not suggesting that it would be, the average cost per day of recalling the Parliament would be in the order of $100,000. That is a matter for the Democrats and others to consider.
—CHOGM was $2m a day or more.

—The interjection is that CHOGM cost $2m a day. The discussion by 43 nations of the greatest problem that the world has-that is, the growing gap between the economies of the rich and the poor-and how to lift up the living standards of what amounts to something like one-quarter of the world's population ought to be value, at $2m or $3m a day.
—Put your money where your mouth is.

—The suggestion is made that we should put our money where our mouth is. This year in the Budget we increased our overseas aid by $100m by putting our money where our mouth is. I am very grateful for the interjections by the Australian Labor Party. I come back to the situation that later today the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) will be before the Senate. We will see whether the Democrats intend to keep their word-by way of statutory declarations on sworn oath on the one hand and, on the other, by way of their clear statement to the media that they would under these circumstances pass the Bills. —The natives get very much aroused on these matters when they are reminded that what they called maintaining their rage over the past six years was completely ersatz rage and had no foundation at all.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, by stating that the Northern Territory Government, the honourable member for the Northern Territory in the House of Representatives, and I view with grave concern the closure in the last few days of the smelter and Gecko Mine at Tennant Creek by Peko Mines, and the subsequent retrenchment of 230 employees by that company. With this in mind, I refer the Minister to negotiations between Pancontinental Mining and Denison Mines and the Northern Land Council to commence the Jabiluka and Koongarra uranium projects in the Northern Territory. Will the Minister use his good offices to expedite finalisation of these negotiations so that construction by the companies can commence and, therefore, create an anticipated peak of 2,200 new jobs in construction work at these two sites, thus offsetting the effect of the Tennant Creek Peko dismissals and the possibility of losing these single men from the Northern Territory work force?

—I am aware of the announcement last week that the smelter in Tennant Creek would close. Like Senator Kilgariff, I regret the loss of jobs suffered by 230 employees which that closure will bring about but would make the point that the decision to close was made on economic grounds alone. That was made clear in the Press release. It does not really relate to negotiations with the Land Council or to matters which affect the Aboriginal lands rights Act. The honourable senator has referred to two negotiations which are proceeding. Negotiations are under way between the Northern Land Council and Pancontinental in respect of the proposed Jabiluka mine, and between the Council and Denison Mines in respect of Koongarra. —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether during his discussions early this year, and I believe also last year, with Japan National Oil Co. and other possible joint venturers in Australian synthetic oil projects, the Japanese interests made it clear that a precondition of Japanese investment would be a guaranteed share of the product? Did he tell Japanese interests that such a precondition was acceptable to the Australian Government?

—I made a statement to the Parliament as well as to all nations and industries that inquired regarding product sharing in terms of synthetic crudes, whether from coal or oil. The Government and I told the Japanese and others, including the Germans, that the Government would accept the principle of product sharing; that is, that if a foreign company were to come into co-partnership in Australia to produce synthetic crudes there would be a principle of some product sharing for that co-partnership. We also said that the individual percentage and nature of product would be determined case by case. We stated further that obviously, when one sets out to liquefy coal or to produce oil from shale one does not know the nature of the precise product until all the work has been done. So the principle would be there but the actual precise arrangements would be dealt with on a case by case basis. Also, the countries have been told quite clearly-it would be clearly understood-that the Australian indigenous oil petroleum market would have to be supplied ahead of any other market. So it is quite understood that we in Australia would aim to keep an energy balance and at the same time, by attracting technology, capital and know-how, provide for synthetic crudes for the future.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am aware of previous statements including an answer to a question on 11 March this year. But no previous statement by the Minister nor that answer has dealt with one part of the question which I would like to put again. Have the Japanese interests-the Japan National Oil Co. and/or other potential joint venturers-made it clear that a precondition of Japanese investment would be a guaranteed share of the product?

—I am not aware that the Japanese or any others have put the matter in that way. For example, the Japanese at the moment are undertaking a pilot plant in Australia on oil shale at their own cost. The understanding is quite clear-that they undertake it and the technology will become known to Australia. But there is no precondition for them at all as regards the journey or the result itself. It is quite clear from the implications of their question to me and others, and my answer, that they would be expecting some share of the product and so would we expect that they should get it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CLOSURE OF RADIO TELESCOPE AT CULGOORA

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology to a report in the Australian of 19 October 1981 which relates to the Government's decision which will cause the closure of a unique solar radio telescope conducted by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation at Culgoora, New South Wales, at the end of 1984. Secondly, what approaches have been made by the Government in an effort to secure the funds necessary to prevent the closure? Thirdly, what action will be taken by the Government to ensure that the many other research initiatives on solar energy, which are being undertaken within Australia, are not affected by future Government cutbacks?

—The decision to mothball the radio heliograph from the end of 1984 was made by the executive of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and not by the Government. It is the responsibility of the executive of the CSIRO to allocate resources within the Organisation. The executive considered that the injection of substantial funds to enable the radio heliograph's continued operation could not be justified. In this event it is facing up to a decision in order that CSIRO's programs are terminated at some stage so that new initiatives of higher priority can be started. No approach has been made by the Government or by CSIRO to secure additional funds in order to prevent the closure of the radio heliograph. The radio heliograph is used for basic astronomical research. It collects information on physical processing which occurs in the sun. But this research is not related to the harnessing of energy from the sun.

FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1981

This Bill will give legislative effect to 27 recommendations of the comprehensive report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. A number of recommendations of the Joint Select Committee were similar to those made to me by the Family Law Council. But, in addition, the Bill will also implement certain other recommendations of the Family Law Council. The Bill proposes the most extensive amendment of the Family Law Act since its initial enactment.

Broadly, the Bill extends the jurisdiction under the Act in relation to property and custody proceedings. It provides that proceedings under the Family Law Act are to be held in open court and, although the absolute prohibition on the publication of details is removed, it prevents publication of details that would identify individuals involved in proceedings. The Bill establishes an Appeal Division of the Family Court of Australia. It enables courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act to attach a power of arrest to injunctions in certain circumstances. It will remove the requirement for the parties or their legal representatives to attend the Family Court in undefended divorce applications and enable the wishes of children of all ages to be taken into account, as appropriate. Certain provisions concerning the removal of children from Australia that were contained in the Migration Act have been revised and will be relocated in the Family Law Act.

The Joint Select Committee recommended that the Commonwealth should legislate to the full extent of its constitutional power with respect to children and property of parties to a marriage. I agree with this view. The present position where, in certain circumstances, proceedings are necessary in both the Family Court and State supreme courts causes great emotional and financial stress. The Commonwealth should, as far as possible, alleviate difficulties and problems caused to people by aspects of the Federal division of powers in the area of family law. If the Commonwealth by competent legislative action can help mitigate animosity and reduce financial hardship it should do so. For instance, why should it not be open to an uncle or grandmother to bring custody proceedings in the Family Court if he or she considers it beneficial to a child? After all, it is the well-being of the child that is the paramount consideration. Further, why should not all children who have been treated as part of the family be dealt with by a single specialist court in a single proceeding?

At present, proceedings under the Family Law Act can be brought only in relation to natural or adopted children of both parties to a marriage. The Joint Select Committee considered this category too restrictive and recommended that it be extended to cover stepchildren and even foster children. The Bill does this. It also extends the Act to cover children born to married women by means of medical procedures, such as artificial insemination, where the husband is not the biological father but has consented to the medical procedure, or the law otherwise deems the child to be the child of the husband. In addition, the Bill provides that a third party may bring custody, guardianship, access or maintenance proceedings in relation to a child of a marriage against a party to a marriage. It will be seen, therefore, that the Bill reduces the number of situations that require resort to two different courts and legal systems.

In proceedings between parties to a marriage concerning property, the Bill gives effect to the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee. At present property proceedings can only be brought in relation to concurrent, pending or completed proceedings for dissolution or annulment of marriage between the parties. The Bill will enable proceedings to be brought by parties to a marriage in relation to the property of the parties or either of them where the proceedings arise out of the marital relationship. This proposed amendment will be of advantage to many persons faced with marital breakdown who wish to secure a settlement of property rights before the period of 12 months separation required for divorce proceedings has expired. I would point out that in a case where proceedings for a property settlement are brought prior to the institution of dissolution proceedings, the court will have power to adjourn the property proceedings to enable the parties to consider the likely effect of the proceedings on their marriage or on any children of their marriage.

Also in relation to the jurisdiction of the Family Court, the Bill implements the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee that the Family Court in the Australian Capital Territory should be invested with as broad as possible jurisdiction in family law matters. There has been for some time a call for the Family Court to be open to the public. The majority report of the Joint Select Committee and the Family Law Council has so recommended. The Bill enables proceedings to be heard in open court but empowers a court to exclude persons from proceedings.

While the Bill relaxes the present total prohibition on publication of details of proceedings under the Act, it provides severe penalties for publication of any account of proceedings or a part of proceedings that identifies a party to the proceedings, a person related to or associated with a party to the proceedings, or a witness in the proceedings. I appreciate that there are strong views held by many that the Family Court should continue to be a closed court and there should be no relaxation of the existing absolute prohibition on the publication of details of proceedings under the Act. The new provisions, in my opinion, strike a fair balance between the conflicting, but equally valid, needs for public scrutiny of courts and for personal privacy in this delicate area of domestic relationships. I also intend to keep under close examination the operation of the amendments proposed to be made under the Bill in relation to these two matters.

As mentioned, the Bill establishes an Appeal Division of the Family Court. A Full Court is to be constituted by a majority of judges from the Appeal Division. This structure gives effect to the present practice of the Chief Judge of the Family Court which, in effect, adopts the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee. The Chief Judge now selects a panel of 11 judges for appeal work and a Full Court consists of at least two of these judges. The other judges sit on at least one Full Court sitting each year. In accordance with other recommendations of the Joint Select Committee, the Bill also renders the Chief Judge responsible for the orderly and expeditious discharge of the business of the Court, thus vesting her with statutory power in respect of the administration and arrangement of the business of the Court that she already carries out in practice.

The Bill will enable undefended divorce applications to be dealt with without the necessity for either of the parties or their legal representatives to attend before the Court. In addition to the savings of expense to the parties mentioned by the Joint Select Committee, I anticipate that there will be significant savings of court time. This will not, of course, diminish in any way the Court's need to be satisfied, on the evidence, that the ground for granting a divorce has been established and that there is no reasonable likelihood that cohabitation will be resumed. As recommended by the Joint Select Committee, the Bill also enables joint applications for divorce to be made. I agree with the Committee that where the parties have mutually agreed to a divorce and the requisite ground has been established the making of a joint application would reduce the costs to the parties and would encourage negotiation and conciliation.

Another significant recommendation of the Joint Select Committee which is implemented by the Bill is that there is to be a discretion given to the Court to attach a power of arrest to an injunction granted for the personal protection of a party to or a child of a marriage or to exclude a person from certain premises. The Court can so attach a power of arrest where it is satisfied that bodily harm has been caused to a party or to a child of the marriage by the person against whom the injunction is directed and that person is likely to cause bodily harm to a party to or a child of a marriage. Under the proposed new section, once a power of arrest order has been made, a Commonwealth or State police officer may, if he believes on reasonable grounds that the person against whom the injunction was granted has, since the order was made, breached the injunction, arrest that person without warrant. A person so arrested must be brought before a court within 24 hours of his arrest or, if a Sunday or public holiday commences within the 24-hour period, 48 hours after his arrest. A power of arrest attached to an injunction will cease to have effect six months after the date specified in the order or on such earlier date as is specified by the Court when making the order. I believe that this amendment will significantly increase the protection available to wives and children who are faced with domestic violence. I am confident that it will assist the police in dealing with this problem.

I now propose to deal with those provisions in the Bill which relate specifically to the welfare of children. Both the Joint Select Committee and the Family Law Council have recommended that the requirement that a court give effect to the wishes of a child of 14 years or more in custody proceedings should be replaced by a provision enabling the wishes of children of all ages to be taken into account to the extent appropriate. The Bill gives effect to these recommendations. This should alleviate the pressure that has sometimes been placed on children of 14 years or more in custody proceedings because of the present provision. The Bill also enables children to avail themselves of the counselling facilities of the Family Court and to initiate custody proceedings as proposed by the Committee and supported by the Council.

The Bill revises and relocates in the Family Law Act the provisions of Part III of the Migration Act that provide offences in relation to removal from Australia of children in respect of whom custody or access orders have been made or sought. This measure was recommended by the Interdepartmental Committee on Prevention of Removal of Children from Australia by One Parent, which considered that the inclusion of the provisions in the Family Law Act would more easily bring to the notice of the public and the legal profession the prohibitions that exist. In addition, penalties for these offences are increased. In relation to abduction of children, the Bill provides that, where a child has been removed from a person legally entitled to the care and control of the child, a court may order that the person wrongly removing the child make reparation to the Commonwealth, a Commonwealth authority or to any other person in respect of the loss suffered or expense incurred by the Commonwealth, an authority or any other person in restoring a child to the person entitled to care and control. This will apply, for example, where the Commonwealth, pursuant to a scheme that has been operating for some two years now, has provided financial assistance to a person in respect of action or proceedings that person has had to undertake overseas to seek restoration of a child in these circumstances. The Joint Select Committee recommended that the Act be amended to include such a provision.

In relation to proceedings under the Act involving the welfare of a child, both the Joint Select Committee and the Family Law Council have recommended that the Act should make a clear distinction between, on the one hand, a conference with a court counsellor or welfare officer, the purpose of which is to attempt to resolve the differences existing between the parties to the proceedings and, on the other, a conference with a court counsellor or welfare officer, the purpose of which is to enable the court counsellor or welfare officer to furnish a report to the court to assist the court in its determination of the matter. The former type of conference should be absolutely confidential, whereas the latter will not be confidential. The report produced as a result of the latter type of conference will be received in evidence in the proceedings and accordingly may be the subject of cross-examination. The Bill makes the necessary amendments to the Act to establish this important distinction. The Joint Select Committee also recommended that the Court should be able to invite the intervention of child welfare officers responsible for the administration of relevant State or Territory laws in appropriate proceedings relating to the welfare of a child. The Bill does this.

I now turn to those provisions in the Bill relating to financial proceedings under the Act. To assist the courts in dealing with difficulties posed in a case where one party to the marriage will become entitled to superannuation benefits in the relatively near future but there is otherwise little property available for distribution between the parties, the Joint Select Committee recommended that the Act be amended to give the court a discretion to adjourn the proceedings to enable a final order to be made in such proceedings when the superannuation benefits are received. The Bill makes such an amendment to the Act. To ensure the effectiveness of this amendment it has also been necessary to provide in the Bill that where one of the parties to property settlement proceedings dies before a final order has been made in the proceedings, then those proceedings may be continued by or against the legal personal representative of the deceased party.

Both the Joint Select Committee and the Family Law Council have recommended that the grounds on which a property settlement order made under the Act can be varied or set aside should be extended. However the Joint Select Committee recommended that such variations be possible in a wider range of circumstances than those recommended by the Family Law Council. Given the policy of the Act that the financial relationships between the parties to the marriage should be determined finally in one proceeding as far as practicable, I have accepted the Family Law Council's recommendation for a narrower range of circumstances in which a property order can be varied. An amendment has also been included to provide that proceedings for having existing property interests declared and put into effect be exempt from the requirement to bring property proceedings within 12 months of the divorce. Such proceedings are, of course, normally available to any persons under the ordinary property law, and it seemed illogical to deprive people of this usual remedy merely because they do not avail themselves of it within 12 months of a divorce. This can, of course, be distinguished from proceedings for property settlement that seek alterations to existing property interests, to which the 12 month requirement will continue to apply.
The Bill makes some amendments recommended by the Joint Select Committee to the provisions concerning the matters to be taken into account in maintenance proceedings, in order to ensure:
That the eligibility of the parties to receive overseas as well as Australian pensions and the like is relevant; and
that the financial circumstances of any cohabitation of either party-not just the applicant-are considered.

I have also accepted and included in the Bill recommendations by the Family Law Council to the effect that orders with respect to the maintenance of a party to or a child of a marriage should cease to have effect upon the death of a person liable to make payments under the order, and to the effect that provisions in maintenance agreements registered or approved under the Act, for the payment of periodic maintenance should cease to operate on the death of the person liable to make such payments, unless the agreement specifically provides to the contrary. I have also accepted a Family Law Council recommendation that there should be a provision in the Act similar to the provision in the repealed Matrimonial Causes Act which permitted the court to inquire into and make orders in relation to property subject to a marriage settlement for the benefit of the parties to a marriage.

A further significant amendment made by the Bill is that the rule-making power under the Family Law Act should be vested in the judges of the Family Court and of State Family Courts. This will bring the Family Court into line with other superior courts in this respect. The Bill also provides for a Rules Advisory Committee to provide advice to the judges in their rule-making capacity. Both of the amendments implement recommendations of the Joint Select Committee and of the Family Law Council. The recommendations of the Joint Select Committee in relation to the provision for offers for settlement in certain proceedings under the Act and in relation to the factors that a court should take into account in making an order for costs under the Act are also implemented by the Bill.

The Bill also makes the amendments that are considered necessary to enable Australia to accede to The Hague Convention on the Recognition of Divorces and Legal Separation and to enable the implementation in this country of the provisions of The Hague Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Decisions Relating to Maintenance Obligations.

The opportunity has also been taken to include amendments to the provision dealing with the recognition and enforcement in Australia of an overseas custody order, to alleviate problems that have arisen from time to time where such an order has conflicted with an Australian order relating to the same child. The effect of the amendments is to enable the Court to either cancel the registration of the overseas order or discharge the Australian order depending on whether or not there has been a change in the circumstances of the child since the making of the overseas order, or whether or not the welfare of the child is likely to be adversely affected by the continuation of the overseas order. The Court may also cancel the registration of an overseas order if all persons having rights under the order agree to its cancellation.

The Bill makes some minor technical amendments relating to the Family Law Council, particularly, for example to enable the remuneration and allowances of members of the Council to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, rather than by regulation.

There are also a number of amendments to be made by the Bill which are of a drafting or technical nature. In this connection, I should mention that the opportunity has been taken to rewrite those provisions in the Act which invest courts with both original and appellate jurisdiction under the Act in a form now considered more appropriate by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. The amendments permitting joint applications for dissolution of marriage and enabling third parties to bring custody and like proceedings have both made necessary a number of consequential amendments to the Act.

Honourable senators will appreciate the breadth of the matters covered in the Bill. Family law is a very personal matter and senators will have individual views. It is for this reason that Government senators will have a free vote on the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MAINTENANCE ORDERS (COMMONWEALTH OFFICERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981
Before I come to deal with the amendments proposed in the Bill, honourable senators may find it useful if I explain the background to the Maintenance Orders (Commonwealth Officers) Act 1966.

The Commonwealth has made statutory provision for maintenance payments for children, wives and, latterly, husbands, where a need for maintenance exists. That provision was contained in the repealed Matrimonial Causes Act and is now contained in the Family Law Act. But the Commonwealth, of course, does not possess unfettered powers to legislate for the payment of maintenance in all situations.

Accordingly, there is an area of maintenance jurisdiction which falls outside the subjects on which the Commonwealth may now legislate and therefore remains to be governed by State legislation. That area concerns maintenance for certain ex-nuptial children and, potentially, maintenance for parties to de facto relationships.

This situation of divided responsibility, with Commonwealth law governing some cases and State law governing others, will probably continue until an appropriate reference of powers by the States to the Commonwealth is made. Until that time, the difficulties occasioned by divided responsibility will remain to be solved. One of those practical difficulties concerns the enforcement of a maintenance order made under State law against a Commonwealth employee.

To overcome this difficulty, the Maintenance Orders (Commonwealth Officers) Act 1966 allows an attachment of earnings or garnishment order made under a State law, to enforce a State maintenance order against a Commonwealth employee, to be directed to the Commonwealth, or a Commonwealth authority, as the relevant employer in a manner similar to that in which it could be directed to a private employer in the State. The Act also deals with the action to be taken where priorities are required to be accorded between two State orders or between a State order and an order under Commonwealth legislation made in respect of the one Commonwealth employee.

The amendments to the Maintenance Orders (Commonwealth Officers) Act 1966-to which I shall refer, for convenience, as the principal Act-set out in the Bill before the Senate fall into a small number of discrete categories: One category is consequential upon Northern Territory self-government and the remaining two upon the Family Law Act. The amendments are technical in nature.

I turn to the first category of amendments-those consequential upon Northern Territory self-government. At present, it is possible that State garnishment orders may be directed to the Northern Territory and its authorities, by virtue of the principal Act. This is because the definitions of 'the Commonwealth' and 'Commonwealth authority' in the Act include, respectively, the Administration of a Territory and a Territory authority.

This situation does not accord with the arrangements for Northern Territory self-government under which matters such as this, because of the Territory's law and justice function and its regulation of its own employees, are properly matters for Territory law.

Accordingly, the definitions I have mentioned are to be amended to make it clear that 'the Commonwealth' does not include the Northern Territory and a 'Commonwealth authority' does not include a Northern Territory authority. Orders made by virtue of the principal Act will then no longer be able to be directed to the Northern Territory or its authorities and it will be for the Northern Territory to make its own law on the subject.

I now turn to the amendments to the principal Act necessitated by the Family Law Act. At present, the principal Act enables moneys to be attached under a State garnishment order notwithstanding that those moneys may be protected from attachment by another law. That other law is, on this point, effectively disregarded.

However, this does not accord with paragraph 106 (2)(a) of the Family Law Act 1975 which enables regulations to be made providing for the attachment of moneys to be paid, inter alia, by the Commonwealth, but not moneys protected from attachment by another law. In other words, under the principal Act, moneys may be attached by garnishment which would not be able to be attached under the Family Law Act and Regulations.
The Bill will change the approach of the principal Act so that it is the same as that of the Family Law Act.
Finally, the Bill replaces a provision referring to the repealed Matrimonial Causes Act with one referring to the Family Law Act. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

The purpose of the Bill is to repeal Part III-Emigration of Certain Children-of the Migration Act 1958-the Act-in order that its provisions may be revised and relocated to the Family Law Act 1975. Part III of the Act at present provides for offences and penalties in respect of the removal and carriage from Australia of children in contravention of custody or access orders that have been made or are being sought. It is considered that the existence of the equivalent provisions in the family law legislation would be more generally known to the public and the legal profession.
The Bill also contains a minor consequential amendment to section 66 of the Act relating to the institution of prosecutions. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DOMICILE BILL 1981

This Bill, which is based upon a model Domicile Bill agreed upon in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, makes four important changes to the common law of domicile. Those four changes are: (a) abolition of the rule of dependent domicile of married women; (b) abolition of the rule of revival of domicile of origin; (c) the age of capacity to have an independent domicile is fixed at 18 years; and (d) new rules are provided for determining the domicile of certain children. Similar legislation has been passed in the Northern Territory and all States, other than Western Australia, where it has been introduced.

A person's domicile is, broadly speaking, the place where the law regards him as having his permanent home. A number of matters affecting personal capacity, such as capacity to marry and to make a will, are determined according to the law of the place in which a person is domiciled. The question where a person is domiciled is now determined according to a number of complex common law rules. At birth, a person acquires his father's domicile, if his parents are married, or his mother's domicile, if his parents are not married. Other rules relate to change of domicile, for example, where a person moves from one jurisdiction to another.

The common law rules do not take account of modern social attitudes relating to the rights of parties to a marriage or the custody of children. Nor do they adequately reflect the increased mobility of individuals, particulardy in a federation such as Australia. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has for some years had under consideration proposals to reform some of these common law rules to more adequately reflect modern requirements. With a view to implementing reform on a uniform basis throughout Australia, the Standing Committee prepared a model Bill. The substantive provisions of the domicile Bill give effect to that model Bill. The successful implementation of this important project is an example of the valuable contribution the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is able to make to law reform in Australia.

I turn to the four major changes the Bill makes to the common law rules. First, clause 6 abolishes the common law rule that a married woman has the same domicile as her husband. At common law, a woman acquires, upon marriage, the domicile of her husband and thereupon has no capacity to have an independent domicile. A wife continues to have the domicile of her husband throughout the duration of a marriage, even if the spouses permanently separate and the husband acquires a domicile, for example, in a foreign country with which the wife has no connection. It is clearly no longer appropriate that a wife's domicile should automatically be the same as that of her husband. Accordingly, the common law rule is abolished and a married woman will have an independent capacity to acquire a domicile of her own.

Secondly, clause 7 abolishes a technical common law rule known as the rule of revival of the domicile of origin. Related to this provision is the provision in clause 10 concerning intention for acquisition of a domicile of choice. Clause 10 provides that the intention a person must have in order to acquire a domicile of choice in a country is the intention to make his home indefinitely in that country. This provision overcomes some problems that have arisen at common law in establishing the acquisition of a new domicile of choice. 'Country' is defined in clause 4 to include any State, province or territory that is part of a country.

Special problems in relation to domicile can arise in a country such as Australia which comprises a number of States and Territories. A person may come to Australia with the intention permanently to settle here but because he works, say, in the construction industry and regularly moves between States he may be domiciled in Australia for the purposes of Commonwealth law but not have sufficient connection with any particular State to acquire a domicile of choice in any State for the purposes of State law. The result is that, for some purposes, he may retain his domicile of origin, even though he has no intention of returning to the country of his birth. Clause 11 of the Bill deals with this situation by providing that a person who is domiciled in a union, but is not domiciled in any particular part of that union, is to be domiciled in that part of the union with which he has for the time being the closest connection.

The third major change made by the Bill relates to the age at which a person is capable of having an independent domicile. Clause 8 provides that a person is capable of having an independent domicile if he has attained the age of 18 years or he is or has at any time been married. This change reflects modern developments relating to the age of majority.

Fourthly, the Bill makes a number of changes relating to domicile of certain children. Under the common law rules relating to domicile, a child born in wedlock acquires the domicile of his father while an illegitimate child has the domicile of the mother. It is not appropriate that a child should automatically have the domicile of one parent if the parents are separated and the child is in fact permanently living with the other parent. The Bill provides that in such a situation the child has the domicile of the parent with whom he has his principal home.

The Bill also contains provisions for determining the domicile of an adopted child. If, upon his adoption, he has two adoptive parents, his domicile is that which he would have had if he had been a child born in wedlock to those parents. If, upon his adoption, he has only one adoptive parent, his domicile is the domicile of that parent or, if that parent dies, the domicile that parent had at the date of death. Where an adoption order is rescinded the court may provide for the domicile of the child.

The changes made by the Commonwealth Bill will apply for the purposes of the laws of the Commonwealth, the Australian Capital Territory, the Jervis Bay Territory and any external territories to which the Act is extended by regulation. The enactment by the Commonwealth, the Australian States and the Northern Territory of the model domicile legislation prepared by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General will bring about, on a uniform basis, important reforms in a complex and technical area of the law. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
DOMICILE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1981

This Bill is consequential upon the changes to be made by the Domicile Bill. Enactment of the Domicile Bill will make these other provisions unnecessary. Accordingly, the Bill provides for the omission of these provisions when the Domicile Bill comes into operation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-
The main purpose of this Bill is to introduce into the Customs Act 1901 new provisions for the valuation of imported goods for Customs duty purposes.
These new provisions are designed to give effect to the Agreement on Implementation of Article VII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
The Government decided in May 1980 to adopt this Agreement on a Free-on-board basis (f.o.b.) so as to exclude the costs of overseas freight and insurance from the Customs value.
This decision took into account the views of State Governments, industry associations and other interested groups within the Community.

Australia's present system of Customs valuation is based upon the Brussels Definition of Value (B.D.V.). This compares each actual transaction with an ideal transaction establishing an entirely open market value in an arms length situation.
The major difference between the GATT valuation and the BDV valuation is that the GATT valuation is a positive valuation system using the actual prices and charges for imported goods.

I will now take a few moments to describe the methods by which a Customs value will be arrived at under the terms of the provisions in Clause 8 of the Bill. Amendments were made in the other place to add precision to these proposed valuation methods following comments on the Bill by interested parties.
For the purposes of the Customs Tariff Act 1966, the value of imported goods is identified by section 156 as the Customs value of the goods.
Section 157 sets out the 6 methods, that are to be applied in sequence, for arriving at the Customs value.

I expect that the first of these methods will be the method most commonly used. This involves the ascertainment of the transaction value of the goods which is determined in accordance with section 159.

The starting point for this method will be the f.o.b. price of goods when sold in a relevant transaction prior to their arrival in Australia. The terms 'price' and 'relevant transaction' are defined in section 154. Before it forms the basis for the assessment of the transaction value, the price may be adjusted, if necessary, in accordance with sub-section 154 (2). Further adjustments may also be necessary under section 159.

The second and third methods are based on the transaction values of goods which are, respectively, identical or similar to the goods to be valued. Section 155 provides the basis for identifying identical or similar goods. Section 160 sets out the adjustments that may, if necessary, be made to the values of the identical or similar goods for the purposes of valuing the relevant imported goods.

The fourth method is based on the deductive value of the goods ascertained in accordance with section 161. This method takes as its starting point the price of the imported goods, or of identical or similar goods, when sold in Australia. Deductions are then made, as necessary, to take account of elements reflected in the price because of the transportation of the goods to Australia and their marketing in Australia.

The fifth method requires the assessment of the computed value of the goods which is to be calculated in accordance with section 161A. This method is based on the costs of production of the goods, adjusted to take account of the costs and profits that usually would have been reflected in sales of those goods when sold f.o.b. for export to Australia.

If all of the methods I have referred to fail to establish a value for Customs purposes sub-section 157 (8) will allow the Comptroller-General to determine the value. In making such a determination the Comptroller-General will be limited by the provisions of sub-section 157 (9).

Section 158 explains the circumstances in which a method of valuation cannot be used. Importantly, a method cannot be used if there is a lack of sufficient reliable information for its use. The first method cannot be used in certain cases, particularly where the relationship between the parties to the transaction influenced the price of the goods.
Section 161C confers a right on the owners of imported goods to be informed of the basis on which their goods were valued.
Finally, section 161D provides that the Comptroller-General may review any valuation made by a Customs Officer and confirm, vary or replace that valuation with another valuation.
Honourable Senators, the adoption of the GATT valuation will bring Australia into line with the valuation system practised by other major trading partners such as the USA, Japan and the EEC.
The Government expects that it will not have widespread consequences for levels of tariff protection now provided to Australian industry.

Reference to the Industries Assistance Commission will however be considered during the first year after introduction of the system if any significant variations in customs duty appear to adversly affect Australian industry or importers.
The Commission has already been asked to include in all future reports recommendations as to the appropriate levels of assistance under the new system.

The new system is also expected to make Customs valuation more predictable for importers. It has the support of most main organisations involved in the importation of goods as well as organisations representing local manufacturers.

The other amendments contained in this Bill are of a formal nature. In particular Clauses 6 and 7 propose amendments to section 151 of the Customs Act to delete redundant provisions following the elimination of British preferential tariff margins in the Customs Tariff Act 1966.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of changes to the Judges' Pensions Act 1968.

The Bill makes three basic changes. First, Judges who are required to retire upon reaching a compulsory retiring age before serving the 10-year qualifying period will be entitled to pro rata pensions after 6 years' service. Secondly, pensions in respect of children of deceased Judges, currently based wholly or in part on fixed annual amounts determined in 1968, are to become a percentage of pension that would have been payable to the deceased Judge. Thirdly, pensions now based on Australian Industrial Court and Federal Court of Bankruptcy salaries are to be based on Federal Court of Australia salaries.

Before describing in detail the provisions of the Bill, I wish to say something about the nature of the pension scheme for Judges under the Judge's Pensions Act. This pension scheme is a non-contributory scheme, in the sense that a Judge is not required to make a contribution from his salary towards the cost of the pension. A non-contributory pension scheme is unusual in public employment. The usual standard in public employment is for a superannuation scheme, to which the beneficiaries make a contribution during their working lifetime. Non-contributory schemes are, however, by no means unusual in the private sector in the case of the most senior employees. But even the contributory schemes in the public sector are financed to a substantial extent from public funds. No superannuation scheme in Commonwealth public employment is financed entirely out of the contributions made by employees. Where a pension scheme is financed in whole or in part by the employer, this should be seen as a part of the total remuneration package for the employment in question.

The salary and pension benefits enjoyed by Judges should be assessed from two points of view, one of principle and the other pragmatic. The independence of the judiciary from the parties to litigation is absolutely fundamental. It is of the utmost importance that a Judge should not, by reason of financial inducement or financial pressure, be thought to be in a position where he may be influenced by a particular party to litigation, whether it be government or a private body or individual. It is therefore necessary to assure to the Judges that degree of financial security which will, in practical terms, put them beyond reach either of inducement or of pressure.

In a federation such as ours, the judiciary, and particularly the High Court, play an even more important role. As interpreters of the Constitution, they rule on the validity of legislation enacted by the parliaments of this country. They maintain the distribution of powers between the Commonwealth Government and the State Governments effected by the Constitution itself. This Senate has itself insisted upon the principle that the Judges should receive no more than the Parliament provides. It is a necessary corollary of this principle that the Parliament should be sufficiently generous in its provision for Judges to ensure them practical independence. Any suggestion that a Judge, on retirement, may be dependent upon the favour of the Executive Government, whether through the payment of ex gratia amounts or by being provided with part-time employment, would run counter to their independence. No Judge should feel himself to be under any financial compulsion when he retires to accept an offer of part-time employment by the Executive Government.

Then there are the pragmatic reasons for a substantial remuneration for Judges. It is proper that Judges should be selected from those who have reached positions of eminence in the legal profession, whether at the Bar, as solicitors or in academic or other pursuits. There are very few persons appointed as Judges who do not accept a very substantial drop in income in taking the appointment. Of course, the offer of appointment as a Judge is regarded as a matter of some honour, and the inducement to accept an appointment is by no means entirely financial. Nevertheless, financial considerations are important and it is essential that sufficient remuneration be offered to attract the best available people.

If the total judicial remuneration is inadequate, then it may be difficult to attract lawyers of ability until they have amassed enough capital to ensure a degree of financial independence for themselves and their families. This may mean that they would not be prepared to accept appointment until late in their professional lives. Again, it is desirable that we should be able to attract people in the prime of their professional careers. It is also socially desirable that judicial appointments should include a number of younger people.

As a consequence of attracting to the Bench people in their 40's-and many judicial appointments are now made at that age-the security of spouse and children will weigh heavily with those appointed. It is therefore proper that any pension scheme should make adequate provision for spouses and for children.

Moreover, we cannot view the pensions paid to federal Judges in isolation from what is done by the States for State Judges. Unless the Commonwealth is able to offer benefits of substantially the same order as those offered by the States, it will not attract its fair share of able lawyers to its courts. A comparison of provisions for State Judges shows that the proposals in the existing pension scheme, varied by those contained in this Bill, are generally comparable with the State provisions except in respect of children. I table, and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, a paper showing the provision made by the States for judicial pensions. The position of children under the existing Judges' Pensions Act has been shown to be inadequate by the unfortunate death of Mr Justice Opas. As a consequence of the appointment of Judges at a much younger age, it is necessary to ensure that adequate provision be made for their children in the event of their death.

Nevertheless, I propose to give some thought to the question whether there should be a change in the basis of the Judges' pensions scheme by making pension rights depend in part upon a contribution being made by the Judges from their salaries. Any change so made would, of course, have to be made in such a way as to preserve existing entitlements. The history of the legislation providing for pensions for Commonwealth Judges shows that there has been a progressive increase in the benefits available, so that the time may come when any additional increase in benefits should be contingent upon an appropriate contribution by those who would share in those benefits.
I turn now to the detailed provisions of the present Bill.

As the Judges' Pensions Act now stands, a Judge must be at least 60 years of age and must have served as a Judge for not less than 10 years to qualify for a pension on retirement. These limitations do not apply where a Judge retires on the ground of permanent disability. Where a Judge dies in office, the pension entitlements of his spouse and children do not depend upon his age or length of service at death.

These provisions were enacted at a time when Judges held life appointments. As a result of the 1977 Constitutional Alterations relating to the retirement of Judges, a compulsory retiring age now applies to new federal judicial appointments. In the case of the High Court, the Constitution itself fixes the retiring age at 70. It also fixes that age for Judges of other federal courts, unless the Parliament provides for a lesser age of retirement. The Parliament has fixed 65 years as the retiring age for Judges of the Family Court of Australia. The retiring age for Presidential Members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is 65.

The effect of these provisions is that, unless he retires on the ground of permanent disability, a Judge who is appointed with less than 10 years to serve before reaching retiring age applicable to the court to which he is appointed is unable to qualify for a pension. What is now proposed by the present Bill is that a Judge who is appointed at an age when he is unable to serve the full 10 years will be entitled to a pro rata pension on reaching the compulsory retiring age, provided that he has served for at least 6 years as a Judge. It is not proposed that a Judge should be able to retire before he reaches the mandatory retiring age, unless it is on the ground of permanent disability, and receive such a pension.

Not to make this kind of provision may inhibit the appointment of Judges of mature years and of considerable experience simply because they would be unable to reach the required length of service to qualify for a pension. On the other hand, a reasonable length of service should be required before the right to a pension accrues. The Bill seeks to achieve an appropriate balance by providing for a pro rata pension on reaching maximum retiring age where a Judge has served at least 6 years. The effect of the Bill would be that a Judge who has served for not less than 6 years on reaching retiring age would be entitled to six-tenths the full pension, that is, six-tenths of 60% of salary. The rate of pension would progressively increase for each additional year of completed service to a maximum of 60% of salary where the Judge retired after having completed 10 years of service on reaching the specified retiring age. Three States, New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia provide for pro rata pensions where a Judge reaches the specified retiring age applicable to the relevant State court after having served for at least 5 years. In Victoria, the retiring age is 72, and there is therfore more latitude for the appointment of Judges who may be able to serve 10 years before reaching that age. In Tasmania, a Judge is entitled to full pension, which is 50% of current judicial salary, on reaching the maximum retiring age of 70 years, irrespective of length of service. In Tasmania, however, the Judges' pensions scheme is a contributory scheme.

The second aspect of the Bill provides increased benefits for children of deceased Judges. The pensions now payable under the Act in respect of children of deceased Judges are based wholly or in part on fixed annual amounts. The amounts were set in 1968 and have not been increased. By way of example, the pension payable in respect of a child who is not an orphan is only $208 per annum. Moreover, fixed annual amounts are not considered an appropriate basis for pension entitlement. Accordingly, the Bill provides for pensions to be payable in respect of children of a deceased Judge based on the pension that would have been payable to the Judge had he retired on the ground of permanent disability on the date of his death.

A number of former Judges and dependants of former Judges are now in receipt of pensions based on the salaries payable to Judges of the Australian Industrial Court. The transfer of the jurisdiction of that Court to the Federal Court of Australia has, for all practical purposes, been completed and the plain fact is that the Australian Industrial Court no longer has any real business. Parliament has already provided for the Court to be abolished when there are no Judges of the Court holding office. It is not appropriate that pensions should continue to be based on salaries payable to Judges of a Court that is now virtually obsolete. The Remuneration Tribunal has recognised that in the lower salaries fixed for this Court.

The Bill provides for pensions based on the salaries payable to Judges of the Australian Industrial Court to be based on the salaries payable to Judges of the Federal Court of Australia. This will also have the effect of restoring, for pension purposes, the relativity that existed until 1977 between Judges of the Australian Industrial Court and Presidential Members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Provision is similarly made for pensions based on salaries payable to Judges of the Federal Court of Bankruptcy to be based on the salaries payable to Judges of the Federal Court of Australia which has taken over the bankruptcy jurisdiction previously exercised by the Federal Court of Bankruptcy.

The Bill also updates references to certain former Papua New Guinea Judges for whose pensions the Commonwealth is responsible and makes provision for applications to be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of certain decisions of the Attorney-General under the Act.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
