TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requests be not pressed.

The Government has considered the requests of this chamber some little time ago to the House of Representatives in relation to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981. On 14 October the Treasurer (Mr Howard) dealt in the House of Representatives with the reasons why the Government is not prepared to accede to the requests. I do not propose to canvass these issues again, much less again and again and again, and again apparently. In short, the Government's attitude has been summed up by the Treasurer on a number of occasions in the course of public and parliamentary debate on this matter. The Government's view, as expressed by the Treasurer, is that these measures are an integral part of the Budget and that the revenue to be yielded is a significant part of the Budget not only for this year but also for future years. If the requests were met, the full year's cost of that decision would be $235m and the cost for this financial year would be of the order of $100m. I cannot believe that the Senate would not be deeply impressed by the effect of those figures on the integrity of the Budget. The removal from this year's Budget of revenue of $100m and in future years of revenue of the order of $235m is an extremely substantial matter. It is for those reasons that the Government has taken the view it has, or expressed in the message that we have now received from the House of Representatives. Accordingly, I have moved that the requests be not pressed.

However, the Government takes a further view in relation to this matter and it is a view which I notice is shared by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and that is that it is not constitutionally proper for the Senate-in fact, there is not strictly speaking a power for the Senate-to press a request beyond the one that has already been made. We are now in a position in which the Senate has made its requests, having exercised the undoubted power that it has and the requests have been, undoubtedly, considered by the Government, considered by the House of Representatives, rejected, and sent back to this chamber. The view taken by the Government, on my advice as Attorney-General, is that the powers of the Senate to make any further requests are now exhausted. It may be true that there are precedents. In the past the House of Representatives has reacted to such requests. On a number of occasions in the past when that has happened the House of Representatives, in dealing with the requests, has challenged the power of the Senate and has dealt with them without prejudice to its stated view that the Senate has not the power to press a request.

When one analyses the constitutional situation, I think it becomes very clear as to why the Senate has not got the power to make a request on more than one occasion-in other words, to press the request or, in the colourful language of Senator Haines, to do so again and again and again.

TALK.START.PARA: —And again.

—And again. The fact that it has been done in the past does not mean to say that it has any constitutional validity. As I have said, the House of Representatives has on a number of occasions over the years actually challenged the power of the Senate. I think the position has become very important in this discussion because of the attitude which has been expressed by the Australian Democrats to the question of the rejection of money Bills and Supply. Apart from the academic interest that one may have in this subject, interest which may be shared only between Senator Evans and myself, although other senators may be included--
—And me.

—And Senator Missen. I am sorry, Senator, I did not realise you were in the chamber. This matter is more than one of academic interest, although it is of academic interest as well. There has been some suggestion that this question really is only of academic interest and therefore we ought not to be bothered about it. I mention that because it has been a view that has been expressed. This question is much more than one of academic interest for several reasons but, in particular, because of the attitude of the Democrats, who have made such a great feature of it, a big feature of it. They even signed statutory declarations about it. I will come to that in a minute.
—Swearing on a stack of Bibles.

—Yes. I think we ought to ask them to do it here formally in front of us because there seems to be a good deal of doubt amongst them as to what they have really been saying about this question. Senator Mason actually read into Hansard what was in the statutory declarations. As I have not sighted the documents, I cannot vouchsafe their contents. I think we all might be interested in them if they were made available to us. I can only go on what Senator Mason has said about them when he read the contents into Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: This question is also of enormous importance constitutionally in that a rejection or failure to pass a money Bill, or any Bill, is the first step towards puting in train the provisions of section 57 of the Constitution, the deadlock provisions which may ultimately lead to a double dissolution. Therefore, this is by no means an academic subject. When the Senate rejects or fails to pass a measure it is looking down the barrel at the provisions of section 57 of the Constitution. I hope that the Democrats have given full consideration to the logical consequences that in the end may result from the course upon which they have embarked. I doubt whether they have. In debating this matter I think it is important for the Senate to fully understand that what it is doing, if it presses its requests, is rejecting this measure. That is my view, the view of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the view of a great many people of even greater distinction than either of us. I will begin with the views of Quick and Garran, the authors of the first Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth. This is a work of enormous authority because the authors themselves were fathers of the Constitution. Sir Robert Garran was the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth for many years and a lawyer of the greatest possible distinction. Page 671 of Quick and Garran's current edition states--

TALK.START.PARA: —Current edition? The current edition is 1901.
—That is the current print of the book. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: There does, however, seem to be a substantial constitutional difference between the power of suggestion and the power of amendment, as regards the responsibility of the two Houses.
It continues:

On the other hand, in the case of a bill which the Senate may not amend, the House of Representatives alone is responsible for the form of the measure; the Senate cannot strike out or alter a word of it, but can only suggest that the House of Representatives should do so. If that House declines to make the suggested amendment, the Senate is face to face with the responsibility of either passing the bill as it stands or rejecting it as it stands. It cannot shelve that responsibility by insisting on its suggestion, because there is nothing on which to insist. A House which can make an amendment can insist on the amendment which it has made; but a House which can only 'request' the other House to make amendments cannot insist on anything.

That was the opinion of Quick and Garran. I will now refer to another opinion given in March 1943 by Sir Robert Garran, then still the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth; Mr Knowles, who became Solicitor-General; Sir Kenneth Bailey who was Solicitor-General for many years; and a Mr Castieau, who was then Parliamentary Draftsman. The statement read:

In our opinion the Constitution in denying the right of amendment and in conferring the rights of request intended a substantial difference. In this we respectfully agree with the views expressed by Sir Harrison Moore, Sir Isaac Isaacs, and Sir John Latham. We think it clear that the Constitution did not intend to stultify itself by giving back in one clause what it had taken away in another. The essence of the difference between request and amendment is that in the case of a request the right of decision as to the form of the Bill rests solely with the House of Representatives. To press a request is to insist upon it which is a contradiction in terms and also in our opinion unconstitutional.

Sir John Latham was mentioned in that quotation as indeed was Sir Isaac Isaacs. Both of them were Chief Justices of the High Court. I will quote from a passage of Sir John Latham who was then Attorney-General of the Commonwealth and, as I said, later became a Chief Justice of the High Court. He stated:

The Senate should recognise that the only practical way in which effect may be given to the words of the section which draw a distinction between making a request at any stage of a Bill, and amending a Bill, is by taking the view that a request can be made known only once, and that, having made it, the Senate has exercised all the rights and privileges allowed by the Constitution.

That appears on page 5249 of Hansard of 30 November, 1933. I think those authorities can be supplemented by others. Mr Hayden, the Leader of the Opposition in another place, when dealing with this question referred to the view of Professor Richardson as he then was, now of course the Commonwealth Ombudsman. In the debate last week Mr Hayden said:
The facts are, . . . that the Senate has the right, constitutionally, to make its request on a particular money Bill once and once only.

Of course, I assume that on a constitutional question of such importance the Leader of the Opposition would not have made such a statement without the advice, consultation and endorsement of the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, the Government is laying the preconditions or the foundations for a double dissolution. We not only welcome such a double dissolution on this legislation but also we challenge the Government to proceed along those lines. We would be delighted to have a double dissolution election at the beginning of next year. Let us make that perfectly clear to the nervous Nellies on the other side and the nervous Nellies who sit, for the time being, behind Prime Minister Fraser in the House of Representatives. We oppose the Government's motion because, although to a limited extent only, it salvages something from our original position on these sales tax Bills; that is, that they should all have been defeated. We oppose the government motion for the same reason as we opposed the Bills in toto; because they are inflationary and on June figures they will add 1.1 per cent to the consumer price index. They are unjust and completely unnecessary. We are opposed to them for all those reasons. We are also opposed to them for macroeconomic reasons.

It becomes increasingly apparent-I have absolutely no doubt that this will be confirmed when the national accounts for the June quarter come out-that the economy, having gone through what was for the Fraser Government a period of high growth in 1980 and in the beginning of 1981, became stagnant about the middle of this calendar year and indeed, economic growth could even be negative at this stage. It is almost unbelievable that, in a period when the unemployment rate was 5 1/2 per cent and rising, that any government since the 1930s could have brought in a Budget to produce a domestic surplus of $1,500m. If that figure is adjusted to take account of the fact that there is an additional pay period this financial year, the effective domestic surplus would be about $1,900m. It is almost unbelievable that, with a stagnant economy and an unemployment rate of 5 1/2 per cent and rising, any government in the 1980s, or even in the 1950s, could have brought in such a Budget. The Bills are inflationary, unjust and unnecessary and they will add to and deepen the recession which is already beginning to be felt. Malcolm Fraser's all-time record interest rates have begun to have their effect on the economy.

Some other facts need to be restated about these Bills and the attitude towards them which the Australian Labor Party has consistently held since it was announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in the House of Representatives the week after the Budget was brought down. These Bills are not, for the most obvious of reasons, Supply Bills. They seek to raise money. Supply or Appropriation Bills seek to spend it. The survival of a government is not dependent upon the passage of the requests which are before us now or indeed the Bills in toto. If these requests were accepted by the House of Representatives, the only effect would be that the domestic surplus budgeted for at $1,500m would be reduced to $1,400m.

A rough analogy, subject to one caveat which I will state later, exists between the Senate rejecting these Bills in part or in toto and the Senate of 1974 rejecting the Medibank levy legislation. In both cases, the Senate sought or seeks to reduce the amount of money which a government sought to raise and the amount of taxation which a government sought to impose. It is highly significant that nobody inside or outside of the Liberal Party has described the Senate's rejection of the 1974 Medibank levy legislation as a denial of Supply or as something which threatened the survival of a government. The analogy breaks down in one respect. The 1974 Medibank levy legislation fulfilled an explicit promise of the then Labor government upon which it had fought and won the 1974 double dissolution election. These Bills and all of the 1981 sales tax measures do precisely the opposite. They seek to break a series of explicit promises given by various people on behalf of the Government.

I think it was on 20 November last that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said that there would be no movement to a broadly based consumption tax unless it was accompanied by massive reductions in income tax. Far from being accompanied by massive reductions in income tax, we now know that this deepening and broadening of the indirect tax base has been accompanied not by a reduction in personal income tax but by a massive 22 per cent increase on the personal income tax to be paid by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. Income tax, which is already at record levels, is to be increased by 22 per cent for wage and salary earners at the same time as the Government seeks to raise on a full year basis an additional $900m through a widening and a deepening of the indirect tax base. The essential difference between what the Senate of 1974 did and what the Senate of 1981 seeks to do is that the Senate of 1974 stopped an elected government from fulfilling its explicit electoral promises. In the Senate of 1981, the Labor Party is seeking to stop the Fraser Government from breaking its explicit electoral promises.

On the question of taxation, it ought also be noted that the Fraser Government is preparing to introduce next calendar year-it may be during the next financial year-phoney tax cuts. The Government is preparing to change the income tax laws in a way which it will describe as having cut taxes. In fact, due to what the Prime Minister repeatedly called at one time the secret tax of inflation, something that was utterly reprehensible according to the present Prime Minister in 1975, at the forecast rate of money income increases-if the same rates are carried on to next year-there will be a real increase in income tax of $1,500m this year. At present rates, without adjusting the tax schedule, real income tax collections, after allowing for inflation and for the fact that next year's dollar will be worth less than this year's dollar, will increase by $1,500m a year. Any so-called tax cut of less than $1,500m introduced in the next financial year will, in fact, be a disguised tax increase. It is very important to know that and to stress it because there is no doubt that the Prime Minister is preparing for phoney tax cuts and legislation, which he will call tax cuts legislation, which he thinks will rescue him, in the first instance, from the Peacock challenge within the Liberal Party and, secondly, from the wrath of the electorate in 1983.

It would be much better, of course, if the wrath of the electorate were shown long before 1983. We would be delighted to allow the electorate to pass judgment on these Bills, the other Sales Tax Bills and on the record level of income taxes which are already being imposed by the Fraser Government and which will increase by another 22 per cent for wage and salary earners. We would be delighted to allow the electorate to pass judgment in a double dissolution election next February on those matters and on the Fraser Government's stewardship of all matters over the long term. After the Government has taken the rejection of its requests which are currently before the Senate as a failure to pass or a rejection of the Bills, we challenge the Government immediately to bring back the Bills in the autumn session of the Parliament next year. Provided that the Australian Democrats do not go to water, we will throw them out again. We would be delighted to have an election.

I will make just one final point. It is being claimed by the Government still and repeated by some gullible journalists that the economy is basically in good shape. Let us examine the facts behind that assertion. On the Government's own forecasts, the inflation rate for the year ending June 1982 will be 11.9 per cent. On the Government's estimates, the consumer price index will increase by 11.9 per cent between June 1981 and June 1982. The Government has forecast a 3 per cent growth in real non-farm gross domestic product. It is now perfectly clear that it will not get anything like that level. The Government has forecast that there will be a slight increase in unemployment over the year. Because of the economic stagnation which will be intensified by these Bills, the increase in unemployment will be much greater than the Government originally expected. In 1975 we were told that the economy was in complete disarray, in ruins, because of inflation, unemployment and the allegedly low economic growth. In 1975 inflation was 13 per cent and falling. At the end of this financial year it will be 12 per cent and rising.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose the motion that these requests be not pressed. I thank the Australian Labor Party for its support in this matter. People say that this is a Democrats initiative. Of course it is not just a Democrats initiative. There is no way in which five senators could do any such thing. It is a combined effort by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to prevent the institution in this country of an unfair and unjust law which has never obtained in this country, a point of principle which is wicked and evil and which is designed to oppress the poor and the middle class people of this country to the benefit of the rich. This is really what the Government is on about. Let us not lose sight of that in all this concern about constitutional problems and matters such as that. That is really what this argument is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point the argument is about is that the Government is doing something which, demonstrably, the people of Australia do not want. The people of Australia have said to the Government plainly and over and over again that they do not want it. They will continue to say that and they want to continue to say that. The Government, of course, does not want to hear it. It wants this matter swept under the carpet. It wants to slink away and leave the murder concealed behind it. There is no way in which any responsible senators can allow the Government to do that.

All the huffing and puffing of Senator Durack-he made a fairly good effort at huffing and puffing-will not blow the house down. I was going to deal with his first point, but I think Senator Walsh has already mentioned it. However, I think it is worth mentioning again. Where will the money come from-this enormous $100m in contrast with the $1.5 billion surplus for which the Government is budgeting this year? Of course the loss of money would not bring down the Government. Of course it would not affect the Government's financial policies one iota if, indeed, it did not go ahead with these ridiculous sales taxes on children's shoes, school clothing, building materials and the means of information.

I do not know where the Government got this idea in the first place although there have been leaks, of course, that there were strong objections to it within the Liberal Party of Australia, even in quite high places. I am pleased to hear that. Now, of course, it is a matter for those Liberal Party senators and members of parliament not to go to water but to recognise what the electorate wants and, even more important, what is right and proper, instead of slinking away and toeing the line as though it were some sort of game between two gangs of 8-year-olds in a school yard, rather than doing what is right and proper for the Australian people. Then I think we might get some good government in this country.

For the very first time we would get the situation in which this House of Parliament would be seen as a House of Parliament which has rights under the Constitution and which has them because those who founded the Constitution knew that there was a need for a second chamber for that purpose-to place a curb on the excesses of the Executive. The Liberal and National Country Party senators feel bound, somehow, to do absolutely what the Executive says. I suggest that that diminishes them greatly as people and as senators. I suggest that our friends on the other side of the chamber ought to examine their consciences very carefully. Indeed, I am hoping to see those Bills back quite soon. I would like to see the Bills back within a week or two with those requests acceded to. I am fairly confident that as the Government is exposed to more and more pressure from the community on this matter it will see good sense in it.

In fact, I was most interested in some of the things that Senator Durack said or hinted at during his speech. Possibly the Government might just let these Bills lie, they might not come back in three month's or six month's. I would be very interested to hear a further view from the Attorney-General on this matter at some later stage. Perhaps the Government sees this as its way out. It knows it has terribly unpopular legislation on its hands. It does not know what to do with it; it does not know how to get out of its dilemma. Maybe the way to get out of its dilemma is simply, as it has done with many other dilemmas in the past, to do nothing. If it does that and the sales taxes on necessities are not applied to the Australian people, that will be to the advantage of everybody concerned.

I must express my concern at the views put in the other place and here that the Senate has no constitutional right to return the requests. The Australian Democrats see this as a quite preposterous assertion. It is an assertion made from the point of view of the House of Representatives and the Executive. It is an attempt by the Executive to gather a gaggle of lawyers around it who will say that the House of Representatives is the only one that has rights. They are trying to read words into the Constitution which, in fact, are not there. That is what is happening. The statements made by Quick and Garran and by others are statements by people on the meaning of section 53 of the Constitution which have no basis whatsoever on any single word or phrase in that section of the Constitution, or anywhere else in the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you the expert?

—I am not the expert. What I say is based partly on what those who know a great deal more about it than I do have said, including the ex-Clerk of this place who takes this view quite strongly. Before I get on to that I would like just to make the point that all of us here are supposed to be senators. We are here in this place with certain duties to perform. I would have thought one of them was to uphold reasonably the constitutional rights of this House and what it has to do on behalf of the Australian community, not to attack them, not to be in leauge with another place which wants to destroy the powers of this place. That is why I suggested to Senator Durack by way of interjection that perhaps he is in the wrong House. Maybe he should go and sit somewhere else if he wants to take that kind of line.
—Enough of this chauvinism.

—That is three times now, Senator Evans. We do not want to contribute to a diminution of democracy in Australia and especially the power of the Senate, which is not a power to bring down governments but a power to say to people that something needs further thought, that it requires further examination. Indeed, this legislation does need further thought. The expressions of opinion by the Australian people have not yet finished. There is much more to come yet.
—Tell us what you are going to do.

—I will tell the honourable senator a story which he will appreciate. It is supposed to be a story of some authority about two previous United States Presidents. It is about a question that Jefferson once asked Washington in relation to why the United States Senate, the second House, existed in the first place. This may well be apocryphal; it does not sound like very good manners. Washington said: 'Why do you pour your coffee into the saucer?' The reply that is said to have been made was: 'Why, to cool it, of course'. Washington's reply to Jefferson is then said to have been: 'That is why we have a second House, the Senate-so that legislation can be poured into it to cool it'. That is what section 53 of the Constitution is about. It has been said that the whole spirit of that section is compromised. It is worth quoting into the record the relevant provision of the Constitution-paragraph 4 of section 53-because nobody else has done so. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may at any stage return to the House of Representatives any proposed law which the Senate may not amend, requesting, by message, the omission or amendment of any items or provisions therein. And the House of Representatives may, if it thinks fit, make any of such omissions or amendments, with or without modifications.

Of course, the House of Representatives over a period has repeatedly questioned the right of the Senate to press the same requests but it has received and considered repeated requests from the Senate on 11 occasions in the past. It is rather ridiculous for us to be told here and now that somehow the Fraser Government has a special mandate over the past. Although something has happened 11 times in this House through the decades, and it has been sanctified by that degree of precedent, somehow the Fraser Government has a special mandate to throw all of that away and it no longer applies. A distinguished lawyer, the Attorney-General, in effect has said to me that such precedent is then of no value, no importance. Where would our legal system be if that kind of nonsense were pressed? On six of the eleven occasions the House has passed a 'without prejudice' resolution, protesting that its consideration of the repeated request did not imply acceptance of the Senate's right to press its request in that way. On two of the remaining five occasions the House made the requested amendments without protest. Odgers, in Australian Senate Practice-a book which is read and regarded highly in this place-says:
. . . that practice warrants the conclusion that the right to repeat a request has, at the very least, been established by usage.

Constitutional lawyers continue to differ on the strict legal position, as the Attorney-General has said. Quick and Garran argue that the House of Representatives remains responsible for the wording of the Bill. We cannot see any inhibition of that by what we are doing. We are simply asking the House of Representatives to give it mature consideration, which it has not done yet. Certainly there is no evidence of it. Eventually it will have the full responsibility, the Democrats hope and believe, of re-writing that Bill so the sales tax on necessities is not there. We do not want to do it; we want the House of Representatives to do it.

The interpretation of the words 'at any stage' in the particular section of the Constitution are rather interesting. I think it is of some importance that in 1898 the Melbourne Federal Convention, which was drafting the Constitution, rejected a motion to substitute the word 'once' for the words 'at any stage' in that section of the Constitution. It was proposed that the Senate may once return to the House of Representatives any proposed law. That was refused and instead the words that the Senate may 'at any stage' return them were insisted upon. When it comes to the views of the people who put together the Constitution there can be no doubt whatsoever about those views. What they thought and felt is a matter of record. I think that shows up for what it really is, this shameful attempt by the House of Representatives to destroy the right of the Senate, under section 53, to cool legislation, to be able to say: 'Look, you people haven't thought about this; we want the public to communicate with you and to give their views'. Because in the past the Government has been used to gagging and guillotining legislation through and making it a fait accompli before the public knows about it, it now does not like the new ball game where the public has the opportunity to consider these things. That, of course, is what democracy is about. Senate Standing Order 252 (3) provides:
Requests to the House of Representatives may be made . . . On consideration of any Message from the House of Representatives in reference to such a Bill . . .
Standing Order 256 provides:

If the Bill is returned to the Senate by the House of Representatives with any request not agreed to, or agreed to with modifications, any of the following motions may be moved: That the request be pressed. That the request be not pressed.

Admittedly these provisions govern the Senate's internal procedures but they do not impose any obligations on the House of Representatives. Numerous pronouncements support the view-they go back as far as 1902-that the Senate is well within its rights to press the request and that there is very little difference for this purpose between an amendment and a request to amend. These pronouncements include the views of Mr Justice, formerly Senator, O'Connor in 1902 and the Right Honourable W. M. Hughes in the House of Representatives. The position remains in dispute between the two Houses, as foreshadowed by Sir John Forrest in the Convention debates. In relation to clause 53, he stated:
. . . is the best compromise we can get between those who wish the two Houses to have equal powers and those who wish the House of Representatives to be paramount in regard to financial legislation.

I want to complete Senator Durack's quotation. He left out a rather important piece of the opinion tabled in the House of Representatives in 1943 by Garran, Knowles, Bailey and Castieau on the whole point of whether requests should not be pressed constitutionally. They said:
The question is not one of strict law, on which the Courts will pronounce.

There are two levels in this debate-firstly, the sales tax Bills themselves, which are important enough, and, secondly, the rights and powers of the Senate not to bring down governments-we renounce that-but to keep complex matters like this in debate long enough for the public to comment on them. The Government is plainly running scared on that last point in regard to the imposition of the sales tax on the necessities of life. It wants the matter taken out of public consideration but it is not our intention that that be done. It is our intention that it remain under consideration. That also is the intention of the Australian Constitution, plainly stated in section 53. Of course it is also the desire of the Australian people that it be kept under consideration. As for the Government waving its fingers and saying 'double dissolution', I suggest that that is a matter on which it is not being honest. That is something which the passage of time will reveal. But I would suggest that meanwhile the Government, in view of all the things that political parties look at-their electoral prospects and other things-might be well advised to look again at whether or not it will remove and never bring in these iniquitous, evil and unpopular sales taxes on the necessities of life.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate must be allowed a reasonable opportunity within which to pass a Bill before it can be said to have failed to pass it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The television stations licence fees were part of the Budget too.

—Were they? That is very interesting. I assure the honourable senator that I do not propose to comment on his speech which was, of course, an attack on the Budget. He is opposed to the Budget. He and his party have abandoned now the principle maintained quite consistently for four or five years while there was no opportunity to do anything about the matter. The honourable senator and his party were then quite consistent--
—Wait a minute; not all.
—No. I am sure there are some honest men opposite, and I am sure they would agree.
—Until you change the power we will use the power.
—I see.
—The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—Senator Walsh made a perfectly honest speech. The Australian Labor Party now honestly wants to get into government and will do anything to get into government. It will abandon the principles in the constitutional convention and elsewhere that it has expounded and abandon the stand on which it has castigated people on this side of the chamber for years. I would suggest that that is an abandonment of principle when it sees what it feels is an advantage just over the horizon. I will not go further with that matter. I have covered that in the speech that I made on the Budget. Everyone can read what the Labor Party said in the past and what it is now saying. It has now adopted the view that little bits of money Bills can be abandoned and those bits that it does not like can be snipped off or removed. It does not matter what that does to the Government's economic program. If the Labor Party is satisfied that that does not upset the Government's Budget, that is all that matters. It does not matter whether the Government thinks it needs the money for particular purposes, as it certainly has declared time and again here.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me not advance into that area because it is at least clear that the Labor Party wants to beat down these Bills. It is the Australian Democrats who are in the greater trouble. They have maintained solid principles in the past and now they want to return these Bills, I think risking again that they may be found to have failed to have passed these Bills and therefore find themselves fighting an election at some stage on that position.

Returning to the Attorney-General's argument, let me say this: I do not accept that there is no power in the Senate to press its requests. As I took him down, he said that 'pressing the request is a contradiction in terms'. I do not agree with that either. To my mind it is possible for a chamber to press on fairly effectively, fairly lengthily, trying to raise public opinion, trying to stir up opinion against a government. That is quite different from a rejection of a Bill. Of couse, it may be said that this is quite different and in fact it is possible to press, to be quite firm, to repeat one's objections and not to pass a Bill at that particular time.

So far as the right to press these requests is concerned, I will not repeat the matters which are set out from ages 406 to 410 in Odgers's Australian Senate Practice. I refer the Committee to the strong statements which were made at the early stage of the debate, when the Senate first pressed for a request, and the remarks-I do not know whether this was quoted-by Senator Sir Josiah Symon, K.C., an eminent South Australian constitutionalist, who argued:

That the words 'at any stage' are equivalent to 'at any step', which means 'at any step in the progress of the consideration of a measure, and such a step is taken when a Committee reports progress, when consideration in Committee is resumed, when the Committee's report is brought up for adoption, and when a Message is sent to the other Chamber.
I would think that that also can mean that when the Bill comes back in due course to this chamber it is possible, likewise, to take it to mean at that stage of the progress of the Bill.

References to various constitutional views which are held are to be found on both sides of the question. There is a House of Representatives view and there is a Senate view. Naturally, the House of Representatives and generally the governments of this country would very much like to feel that there was no possibility of Senates constantly pressing for changes and causing them embarrassment. It does not follow from that that the Senate should come to a conclusion that it does not have that power. It is worth bearing in mind that there are Standing Orders-they are set out in Odgers book, and they are known to us-which provide the way in which we deal with and can press requests. Standing Order 256 indicates the various things that we may do. It indicates that the request may be pressed, that it may be not pressed, and so on. These things are contained in the Senate Standing Orders. In the last five or six years-until recently-we on this side of the chamber have had a majority in both chambers. In this chamber, if it were the will of the majority then, we could have removed or amended those Standing Orders. I am not aware of any attempt being made whatsoever during that period to alter the Standing Orders. I am pretty sure that if such an attempt had occurred I would have been somewhat critical of it. The Standing Orders of the Senate remain as they have been and I think we should pay some attention to them. It may well be that this matter will never be litigated. It may be that the High Court of Australia may never come to any conclusion. It may not intervene. But I think that we in this chamber are obliged to form opinions as to what is the correct interpretation. I refer to the late Right Honourable W. M. Hughes who, of course, was an Attorney-General of this country. In addressing the House of Representatives when the Senate first pressed its request in 1902, he said:
I firmly believe that the Senate is acting quite within its rights.
Dealing with contention that the Senate had the power to make but one request, Mr Hughes said:
If any man had dared to stand up and tell the smaller States that the Senate had only such a power, the Constitution would never have been accepted.
I suggest that we should bear in mind that that was the view held at that time when it was first done, and it has been done 10 times since then.

Further, I do not believe that this chamber should press its request. I believe that the Government has considered and re-considered the request which we have made. Many of us have made our representations to the Government. I have been critical in this chamber of a number of the sales tax provisions, but the Government has decided that that is the way in which it wants to expand its tax base. It is a decision that it has made, one that it must stand by. If it does not propose to change, I suggest that it is not incumbent upon us, or desirable, that the Senate should now risk the possibility of creating a failure to pass, risk the possibility of an unnecessary election in this country by pressing such a request.

I will vote for the motion. Mind you, I did not hear its precise language. I came in a little too late, and I have not noted that a copy has been distributed to honourable senators, but that is the way in which we conduct our business these days; it is really extraordinary. We have not a copy on our tables, but on my understanding of the motion I believe that we should not press our requests and therefore I will vote in that way. However, it will not be for the reasons that the Attorney-General has given to us today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is reminding me increasingly of the junior wart, George Washington-unable to tell a lie, incapable of any immorality, squeaky clean.

May I make it clear to the Senate that, although I have not hesitated on occasion to be rude both to Senator Baume and to various American presidents, I did not in fact refer to either on this occasion as being a 'wart'. I simply stuttered over the word 'George'. Be that as it may, I think it is of some relevance to what I am about to say, because it does deal with matters of political morality and immorality. I do want to have something to say about questions of constitutional law and principle and to political principle, the kind of questions that were called very much in aid by Senator Durack in supporting the motion.

At the outset I want to deal with the canard, for such it is, that there is some kind of unity ticket in this Parliament between Senator Durack on the one hand and Bill Hayden, the Leader of the Opposition, insofar as both are committed to the proposition that the Senate has no power to press a request on more than the initial occasion. It is true, of course, that Bill Hayden did say in the House of Representatives that the Senate has the right constitutionally to make its request on a particular money Bill 'once and once only'. But that ought to be read in the context of the remarks which immediately followed that statement. He said:

That is the opinion of Garran, Sir Harrison Moore, Sir Isaac Isaacs and Sir John Latham. They are unequivocal in their declaration. To go beyond that, it is their separate view but consistent in all cases, that the Senate is no longer proceeding with a message to the House of Representatives but is virtually demanding an amendment to the legislation and, therefore, is taking steps which are prohibited by section 53 of the Constitution. In those circumstances, the Senate's action has to be interpreted as a rejection of a money Bill. Having sent the message to this House once and its being rejected and sent back to the Senate, if the Senate proceeds with it again the matter then moves into the purview of section 57 of the Constitution-failure to pass.

It seems to me very clear that all that the Leader of the Opposition is there saying is that the Senate cannot claim to make a request with impunity on more than one occasion; that there are sanctions which follow from doing that, namely, the sanction of immediately setting in train the 'failure to pass' mechanism which may result in a double dissolution. It is not that the Senate cannot do it or that it would be the subject, if it could ever come to court, of a court order directing it not to exercise this particular power to press a request. It is rather that, if the Senate does press such a request, sanctions will be attached to it. I believe that is the way in which Mr Hayden's remarks have to be understood. That is very different indeed, of course, from the proposition that was put today by Senator Durack.

I personally believe it to be strongly arguable that the Senate does have the power to press a request. Strange as it may seem, perhaps, for me to be saying anything at all which could nourish the pretensions to power of this chamber, as a matter of strict law probably it is the case, on balance, that the Senate does have the power. Certainly, the language of section 53 seems on its face, for a start, to be clear enough when it says that the Senate 'may at any stage' press a request-language which, of course, has been the foundation for the 11 occasions in this century on which requests have been pressed. In respect of some of these at least, the House of Representatives has responded without any protest at all, and in respect of many of which it must also be said that the Labor Party has been party to the Senate majorities involved.

I simply make the point that strong reasons would be needed to overcome the fairly clear language that does emerge on the face of section 53 about the power to make a request being available at any stage. Perhaps the strongest reason which is advanced to overcome that reading is that it would produce, on the face of it, no appreciable difference between a power on the one hand to make a request and a power on the other to make an amendment to a Bill which-if that were so-would render nugatory the distinction that the Constitution seems anxious to make. But to that extent I believe that it is difficult to argue that the delegates to the Constitutional Convention were other than only too well aware that they were making a distinction that was semantic rather than real. They did, after all, reject in Melbourne at the 1898 Convention a motion to substitute the word 'once' for the expression 'at any stage', and there is ample evidence from the transcript of that Convention that the delegates knew they were making an essential linguistic distinction that might be construed by subsequent generations as not having much force and effect. So much, indeed, was let out of the bag by Sir John Forrest, when he said that section 53:
. . . is the best compromise we can get between those who wish the two Houses to have equal powers and those who wish the House of Representatives to be paramount in regard to financial legislation.

So far from being pillars of complete political virtue, our founding fathers were, of course, just as prone to the political arts of compromise and linguistic disguise as any of their successors. It is really that kind of exercise that confronts us in the language of section 53.

It would be a strong reason for construing the power to make a request as being a limited one, one that could not be used on more than one occasion, if it was clear that no sanctions followed from the exercise of such a power, if the Senate could go on making requests without any particular responsibility or prospect of penalty attaching to it for choosing this particular course. If that was a possible reading, from the whole context of the Constitution, as to how section 53 should be interpreted, I believe that there would be grounds for saying very strongly that there is no such power to press a request. Of course, it is clear-I believe I can say by universal consent of the legal commentators and writers on the subject-that there are such sanctions and that a continually pressed request involving the obstruction of the passage of a Bill must be treated 'as a failure to pass' such as will give rise to the potential operation of section 57, and that potentially will set in train the double dissolution mechanism.

Therefore, I believe that, although there are certainly arguments on both sides, and the matter is arguable both ways, there is ample justification for the Senate on this occasion, provided there are other reasons in principle to justify its so doing, to continue on the course that was set when the matter was last debated.

The only real technical question that remains unresolved is as to when the time begins to run. Does it run from the time of the original request, made in this instance on 23 September, or rather only from the occasion-presumably today, a month later, 20 October-when the request is repeated. Or may indeed it be some future occasion when our intentions perhaps are made a little clearer-at least so far as my colleagues on my left, the Australian Democrats, are concerned. There may be a future occasion on which it becomes clear that we really will press a request to fruition and are not just involved in the kind of gamesmanship and grandstanding that, I say with respect, my Australian Democrat colleagues seem to be engaged in during this exercise.

The question is: Do we get, in effect, a kind of free go in regard to making a request to the House of Representatives before time starts to run, before the section 57 three months potential double dissolution clock begins to tick into operation? On that question, again legal opinion is divided. I do not think there is much utility in canvassing here and now the question of when time does commence to run. I know it is of some interest to the Democrats because they have become--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your view on that?

—My view, for what it is worth, is probably that time does begin to run from the first request and not the second one. I cannot see any particular justification constitutionally in principle for giving us a free go. I think if we engage in the business of making a request we are just as much obstructing the passage of Government business as we are by passing an amendment and for that reason we ought to be prepared to bear the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: But I go on to make the point that all these legal issues of which the Government-Senator Durack particularly-makes so much today can in fact be tested if the Government genuinely believes that the Senate is acting in a misconceived fashion in responding as it does on this legal question and making, as it does, these claims of power. It is the case that the High Court cannot step in at this stage of the business and make an analysis of the extent of our powers or practice and precedent. Against that, it equally is the case that the High Court can resolve these matters if the preconditions for a section 57 double dissolution are argued to be satisfied, if three months does pass between the successive presentations of these Bills. If the Government summons up courage in early January, February, March or whatever and puts the Bills back to us in their original form, circumstances will undoubtedly exist for a test case to be resolved at anyone's instance to determine whether the section 57 preconditions are satisfied, whether there has been a failure to pass, when that failure to pass in fact commenced to operate and whether, indeed, there is any power at all for the Senate to obstruct, by a further request, the passage of a Bill of this kind. These are the matters that are undoubtedly now accepted as being within the High Court jurisdiction following the cases of Cormack v. Cope in 1974, the PMA case, and the Territory Senators case in 1975. Whatever else, it is clear that these issues are justiciable in a way that was not necessarily believed likely to be the case when Garran and the rest of them were writing their opinions, not to mention when Quick and Garran were writing their book in 1901. It is now the case that these matters are justiciable and that adds further colour to the challenge that was thrown out by Senator Walsh earlier in this debate.

If the Government really wants to take these points, if it really wants to claim that these powers do not exist, if it really wants to argue that the Senate is behaving unconstitutionally in pressing this matter, it has a lovely opportunity open to it to test the matter, and that is to press the matter to a double dissolution, to claim that the preconditions for a double dissolution exist and to seek to put the matter before the electorate. That will not only be a test of the Government's political will but also it will test the constitutional law of which so much is, I suspect rather hypocritically, being made by the Government today. The point is, of course, that the Government does not want a double dissolution on this issue or, for that matter, any other issue. It knows that we on the Opposition side would be only too happy to accommodate it in respect of such a double dissolution. In saying 'the Opposition side', I cannot extend that description entirely to my colleagues in the Australian Democrats because it is very obvious that they do not now want a double dissolution either, for reasons having, I fear, nothing much to do with principle but everything to do with expediency and with their own political survival, which they know to be very much at risk in the light of the evidence recently and nicely provided for them by the New South Wales voters.

In fact, it is interesting in charting the tortuous path of the Australian Democrats in this debate to note that, even on the question of the time that they are going to allow to run before they cave in, the Democrats have been speaking with a multitude of different voices. When Senator Mason first foreshadowed the Democrats' strategy, if it can be dignified with that description, at the time of the Budget debate, no particularly precise time limit was set. It was simply a matter of Senator Mason saying: 'Time has to be allowed for the electorate to pronounce on this matter, for the Government to reconsider it'. I acknowledge that there was no time limit stated then. But when time limits began to be thrown around, the time limit that constantly recurs in the Democrats' speech making-for example, from the mouth of Senator Haines as recorded at page 575 of Hansard of 9 September-was 1 January 1982, the commencement date of the proposed sales tax legislation.

By about 16 September, Senator Mason began to float the notion that three months might be the crucial period because of the double dissolution neurosis syndrome. But on 23 September, Senator Siddons was heard to say once again that the relevant date, the crucial date, in determining the Democrats' response and the date on which they would cave in would be 1 January 1982. I am not surprised that the Democrats are in a bit of a muddle about this one and anxious to disguise their views on the timing issue. They have an unenviable reputation for chaotic unpredictability and I can understand them, having so little record or reputation for anything else, wanting to preserve what reputation they do have.

The final point I wish to make it that the Australian Labor Party, by contrast, is only too happy to create in this instance some of the preconditions for a double dissolution, not out of sheer malice or bastardry--

. . . at the Melbourne session of the Federal Convention in 1898 an amendment was moved to substitute the word 'once' for the words 'at any stage'. The proposal was defeated on the voices, which is indicative of the Convention's view that the Senate should not be restricted to one suggestion only.
