I do not object to a tax on books-the so-called tax on knowledge-because plenty of civilised countries have it and I do not believe it is a deterrent to knowledge. I think the tax on newspapers and news-type magazines and periodicals is unfortunate and will be a considerable annoyance to the public and to others who are involved in the tax. For example, I am informed that, if one has a subscription to a publication which is paid for and posted from overseas, one has to pay the tax to the post office. For a matter of a few cents on each occasion, people will be required to go to post offices and bail out their magazines.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.

—That is not correct, Senator? There is some information in writing to that effect from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. That makes me wonder about one particular item that I think will affect a considerable number of Australians. I give as an example the National Geographic Magazine, which is an excellent magazine. When one joins the National Geographic Society, the magazine is posted from overseas. I wonder whether that magazine will attract a tax. I am not suggesting that there is any question of discretion in the quality of the magazine and whether it should attract a tax, but I do know that it is an extremely popular gift. This magazine is given as a Christmas gift to a large number of other people.
—You don't know that at all. You don't know whether they read it.

—I know that all the gifts of that nature I give are very gratefully accepted. Perhaps people are not telling me the truth when they say that they enjoy the magazine. I wonder what position I am putting the recipients of my gifts in if I am going to take subscriptions to magazines from overseas which I consider to be excellent, but cannot pay the sales tax component because the money for the subscriptions goes overseas and the recipients of my generosity will have the annoyance of having to pay tax every time they collect a copy of the magazine. I think details like that will come out, which I hope will persuade the Government to look at some of these silly aspects. I hope that the Government will realise that the tax is not going to be a large revenue earner but could be a major annoyance.

SPEECH.PARA: Housing is already heavily taxed at a number of levels and in different ways. The question there is essentially: What is our national policy on home ownership? Doubtless, tax will eliminate a number of borderline cases. However, the principle of whether we try to keep the cost of housing low in Australia-one of the most significant factors in our standard of living-is one that ought to be debated objectively. The general issue of the imposition of the tax is one that I believe the Government will probably have to review and to reconsider. If there is to be a further move in the direction of indirect tax, accompanied by a diminution of the level of direct tax, I hope that these sorts of items will be taken into account. For Senator Walsh's benefit, I repeat that I shall be voting for Senator Durack's motion and shall not be voting for the requests to be pressed because this is a major budgetary measure. I accept that the Government has the right to implement this budgetary measure. I am earnest in the hope that it will see, as it has in other instances, the errors inherent in some details of its policy and re-consider the matter in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two issues about the subject which Senator Martin was discussing a moment ago. I was interested in the interjection of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) in speaking about the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax which is to be applied on magazines which are imported. From her interjection, I understood that this was not to be the case. To put the record straight, I want to read into Hansard a letter from Mr R. A. Gill, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Perth, dated 9 October, to Mr G. W. Pidcock of 30 Edward Street, Bedford. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir
SALES TAX
Receipt is acknowledged of your letter dated 19 August 1981 concerning the proposed sales tax applicable to magazines.

In this regard, legislation currently before Parliament proposes to impose sales tax of 2 1/2 per cent on certain categories of goods that are presently exempt from sales tax. The tax is to be imposed on goods which, on or after 1 January 1982, pass the point at which sales tax becomes payable.
Magazines, newspapers and books are some goods that will be affected by the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax unless an overriding exemption applicable to particular industries and organisations is claimed.

There is no provision in the sales tax law to provide exemption on the magazines purchased by you and therefore sales tax will be payable at the time the magazines go into home consumption in Australia. Sales tax will be payable at the post office at the time you receive each magazine.

Mr Pidcock has written to me because of his concern that if he subscribes to an imported magazine which costs the equivalent of an Australian dollar he will be required, firstly, to go to a post office and, secondly, to pay 2 1/2c sales tax. He is undecided as to how he can achieve that. He cannot interfere with the coin of the realm, but that is the only course open to him, on the determination of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, to pay for his magazines as they come, as the Deputy Commissioner describes it, 'into home consumption'. I think that the Government has to get its act together. It is constantly placing people in the community at a disadvantage. I would suggest that many people who subscribe to magazines are already disadvantaged in that they are housebound for various reasons. Some of them-I know that this is hard to believe-are even physically handicapped and would find it impossible to get to a post office. This is why they subscribe to magazines. I question whether any provision was made by the Government, when it determined that this 2 1/2 per cent sales tax would apply to magazines, for handicapped persons to be able to pay that 2 1/2c on a dollar subscription at home. Will such people be able to post an amount of, say, 50c to the post office? Will they be able to give it to the postman and say: 'Put this on the slate and when it runs out let me know', or will there be some other mechanism by which they can pay their 2 1/2c tax?

We have heard a lot from the Government on the issue of sales tax not being applied to foodstuffs. Let me inform the Government that if it checks in the supermarkets it will see already the effect of sales tax on foodstuffs. Already retailers are making a profit at the expense of the consumers and they are going about it in a very neat way. They are telling us that because a sales tax is applied to the packages in which goods are placed they are quite entitled to charge that 2 1/2 per cent or whatever the particular percentage may be. In actual fact, the price of food is being increased by the Government's decision to apply sales tax to packaging. Unless the Government has some valid reason for imposing this extra payment on families, particularly low income families, I think it has to accept that the Senate has a justification and a right to continue to send these requests back to the House of Representatives until the Government gets its act together and determines, firstly, that there will not be an impost on food and, secondly, that there will not be such stupid provisions as this 2 1/2 per cent tax applied to subscriptions to magazines from overseas.

Like Senator Martin, I also give the National Geographic Magazine to a number of friends of mine. I hesitate to think what they will think of me because now for imposing this additional amount on them. The National Geographic sells for, I think, $1.50. We are aware that Mr Pidcock has been getting uptight about how he is going to pay 2 1/2c. I wonder how my friends will pay 3 3/4c., which will be the tax applicable to the National Geographic. This ridiculous situation will be exacerbated. As I have said, unless the Government can come to terms with these simple items, it will find itself in a lot of strife when it tries to make a comprehensive assessment of those major items on which it is determined to apply a tax which does not already apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a motion moved by the Government that the requests which we as a Senate forwarded to the House of Representatives in respect of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) be not pressed. I do not intend to canvass the subject matter of the Bills as I have done so on previous occasions, but I do wish to point out to the chamber the incongruity of the motion proposed by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that the requests be not pressed, together with his statement that the Senate does not have the right to press those requests. I think that in a debate such as this we sadly miss Senator Cavanagh. I could just imagine what he would do with that type of action from the Government front bench. I have mentioned that Senator Durack indicated that the Senate did not have the right to press the requests. I think I may be slightly in error there. I should have said that Senator Durack came into the chamber with an armful of legal opinion to suggest that the Senate did not have such a right.
—He said that it was only a view.

—Yes, I think that is probably fair to Senator Durack. If Senator Durack is of the opinion that the Senate does not have the right to press those requests he ought to get up and say so. If he wishes to pursue that course, let him take the matter to the High Court of Australia, if he can. There lies the nub of the issue. At this stage he cannot take the matter to the High Court because we are dealing with proposed laws. We are not dealing with laws that have already been passed; we are dealing with proposed laws. The method by which we deal with those proposed laws is the business of the Parliament. It is not the business of the courts. If the House of Representatives has a view about this matter, which it has expressed on some but not all occasions, and if the Senate has a contrary view about it, it is not beyond the realm of possibility that there should be a conference between representatives of both Houses of Parliament to resolve the issue. The armful of legal opinions is of no value whatsoever in view of the fact that we are dealing with proposed laws. I will quote one of the opinions which I understand the Attorney-General put forward. It is the opinion of R. Garran dated 13 March 1943. On the first page this opinion states:

SPEECH.PARA: On each occasion when the House of Representatives has reserved its own constitution position the Senate has recorded a declaration of its own constitutional right to press or re-iterate a request. The practice of the Parliament therefore has left this difficult question unresolved.

It is also true to say that not on every occasion has the House of Representatives adopted the attitude that the Senate does not have the right to press these requests. I submit very briefly, because we have canvassed all of these matters in regard to these Bills ad infinitum before, that the motion put forward by the Attorney-General, 'That the requests be not pressed' is inconsistent with the viewpoint expressed by some Government members that the Senate does not have the power to press those requests. Clearly we do have the right under Standing Order 256 to do just that. Standing Order 256 states:
If the Bill is returned to the Senate by the House of Representatives with any request not agreed to, or agreed to with modifcations, any of the following motions may be moved:
That the request be pressed.
That the request be not pressed.
That the modification be agreed to.
That the modification be not agreed to.

The Attorney cannot have it both ways. He cannot pick and choose which Standing Orders he considers are appropriate to the Senate and which are not because all of those Standing Orders are appropriate to the business of the Senate. I, as a senator, have the responsibility to proceed in accordance with those Standing Orders.

Finally, I would like to advert to the possibility of a valid argument being advanced that the Government may regard the Senate pressing its requests as failure to pass the legislation. That is another opinion. There is more weight in that opinion than in the opinion that we do not have the power to repeat the requests. Nevertheless, at this stage I do not hold to that opinion either. As I have said, there appears to be more weight to that opinion. If the repeated request does form the basis for action to be taken pursuant to section 57 of the Constitution, so be it. The Government can turn around next year or three months from tonight-as I see it-and reintroduce the legislation. Let us see what happens. Let us see whether the Government is prepared at that stage to go to a double dissolution on the issue of the taxation of housing materials or babies nappies. I should think that it would not.

As to the constitutional situation, at that stage it would be up to anybody to test the action in the High Court because decisions and steps would have been taken towards implementing the provisions of section 57 which, of course, could be subject to an action in the High Court. My view at present is that it is completely premature for the Government to adopt the attitude it has adopted. I am heartened by the number of Government members who hold strongly to the view that the Government's attitude on this matter is not correct and that the Senate does have power, in fact, to press these requests. I oppose the motion proposing that the Senate not press the requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly in this absurdly titled debate on the motion: 'That the requests be not pressed'. It is an extraordinary thing for people to be debating. I do so largely because of some misapprehensions and historical inaccuracies which have occurred in the contributions to the debate that have already been made by various honourable senators. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I listened to the replay of the agony of Senator Missen, which was most manifest in 1975. His recollection of those events in 1974 and 1975 now appears to be somewhat different from mine. I heard with interest Senator Martin say: 'I accept the right of the Government to pass all its Budget measures'.
—Not my Government.
—Not her Government. The Government which she supports.

—I think that is what she said: 'I accept the right of the Government to pass all its Budget measures'. That reminds me of Senator Missen's speech. The distinction which the Australian Labor Party has drawn between what is happening now in relation to the Labor Party's intended vote on this issue as I understand it-of course I cannot speak for all my colleagues; they all make up their own minds-and what happened in 1974 and 1975 needs re-emphasis. I am so glad that Senator Missen has come into the chamber. I remember in 1975 Senator Missen's personal agony-if I may so describe it-over a decision by the majority Opposition of the Senate at that time to fail to pass legislation which was designed to bring about the defeat of the Government. Indeed, if there needs to be any doubt about its design of bringing about the defeat of the Government, the friendly interjector, Senator Withers, very explicitly put in Hansard in 1974 what it was all about. Of course, he is not quite in a position now where he can make those threats in the same way as he did then. But it is worthy of memory that what Senator Withers had to say about this issue was very carefully documented.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975-to use Senator Withers's expression-the then Opposition embarked upon a course to bring about the defeat of the Government. We are not, in voting against this sales tax legislation, embarking upon a course to bring about the defeat of the Government and we will not so embark upon such a course in the Senate. I was disappointed to hear earlier today Senator Missen take up the refrain of Senator Carrick. I use the expression 'refrain' because Senator Carrick's debating techniques remind me of a sort of Port Said hawker-when you get on a good thing, keep flogging it. The particular phrase which Senator Carrick is now stuck on challenges the alleged veracity of the Australian Labor Party 'maintaining its rage', as he puts it. Senator Carrick has put this phrase into the ever vacuous head of Senator Missen, who has taken it up and used it as his own. I make the point in terms of 1974 and 1975 and what is now happening in the Senate to remind Senator Missen and Senator Martin about the Budget of 1974 because in that Budget the then Liberal-Country Party majority in the Senate rejected the Medibank levy, which was an essential and important part of the Whitlam Government's Budget legislation. Senator Missen did it in 1974 with no agony and with no sweat.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—That is absolutely true and it is exactly the same sort of thing as we are doing now, I am sorry to say, with no agony and no sweat because it is a small part of the Budget legislation. In 1974 when the Medibank levy was rejected the Whitlam Government said, 'That is bad luck; we have had our legislation rejected in the Senate; so we will have to do it another way'. The fact that it was forced to do it another way was an awful thing for this country, as has been seen by the five changes to the health insurance system of this country since then. That system still is not working. It was an awful thing that the Whitlam Government had to go and do it in another way, but that is what it did. That is what this Government will have to do when this sales tax legislation is rejected. There is a very clear distinction between that course of action by a majority Opposition in the Senate and the course of action upon which honourable senators opposite embarked, as a majority Opposition, in 1975. It is in respect of that course of action that the expression 'maintain your rage' was invented and will continue to live and exist in this country. It is a vastly different thing from the sort of exercise which is being indulged in now by the Opposition. Let that be made quite clear. I am disappointed to see a man of Senator Withens's--
—Hey, hey, hey!
—I nearly called him 'Mithers' or 'Whissen'. That is an unfortunate identity for both honourable senators.
—Your colleagues have not maintained their rage against the Democrats.

—The honourable senator should not be worried about us in relation to the Democrats. If he wants to lecture them there are plenty of opportunities for him to do so. I was disappointed to hear Senator Missen regurgitating the agony of 1975 in the context of the current debate because it has nothing whatsoever to do with it, and he knows it. I can point not just to one instance between 1972 and 1975, as I have done, but also to other occasions when he voted against Budget legislation, if one likes to call it that, which was essential to the program of the Whitlam Government.
—And for which we had a mandate.

—As Senator Evans rightly points out, it was legislation which was put to the Australian people before we faced an election, not like this sneaky stuff involving the sales taxes where every suggestion was made that no indirect tax would be introduced by this Government, until two days after the election when the first news started to filter out about a proposed indirect tax of this kind. That is when it all started to happen-two days after the election. The notion of mandate which was, I think, coined by the then Opposition in the Whitlam period of government is not one which falls naturally upon the shoulders of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other issue I want to touch on is the question raised by my colleague, Senator Walsh. Part of the reason the action was taken in 1975 allegedly was because of the economic performance of the Whitlam Government. Senator Walsh went through, in the course of his speech this afternoon, four major indices of economic performance in respect of which the record of the Fraser Government is abysmal and shonky. Little hope for the future is gained from the indices of inflation, unemployment, interest rates and so on which were mentioned by Senator Walsh. Of course that issue goes to the question of the Government's economic credibility. We are told by this Government that this bit of sales tax legislation, to raise about $100m this year, is essential to its budgetary strategy. What a lot of bunkum. What is essential to the Government's budgetary strategy? Clearly the Government has no idea. All the indicators on which the Government's Budget strategy was based are now going down the chute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you entitled to tell the Government, then, which are the essentials?

—No, that is not why we are telling it. The honourable senator knows why we are telling the Government it; it has nothing to do with its budgetary strategy. He knows why we are voting against the sales tax legislation. It has nothing to do with that.
—You just want to get into government.

—I am just dealing with the justification given by some of the Government spokesmen for the absolute necessity for this legislation to be passed. It has no credibility whatsoever in the overall economic context. I take it the chamber will be surprised to hear that for the reasons I have enunciated I will be voting against the motion that the requests be not pressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Button for making the Opposition's position quite clear. As the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) said earlier in the debate today, the Government has given careful consideration to the requests that were made by the Senate for changes to the sales tax Bills. I do not wish to add to the constitutional argument that was put by the Attorney-General. Perhaps there is no need to say again at this stage that the Bills would impose a 2 1/2 per cent rate of tax after 1 January next year on a range of commodities which are at present exempt from sales tax. We have heard the figures that relate to the Bills. The measures were expected to yield $132m in this year and $330m in a full year. That was stated in all of the Budget documents and I do not think anyone argues about that. I do not think anyone has been arguing that they are an integral part of the Budget. To agree to the requests made by the Senate would significantly alter the Budget proposals of the Government. Therefore the Government has made it quite clear that it does not accept the requests made by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be said-as it has been said-that the loss of $100m or $200m here and there cannot be accepted lightly as it would damage the Budget but I think the Government has come to the conclusion that it cannot accept the amendments that were requested and maybe we ought to address ourselves to some of the points that have been made. I think it has been a fascinating debate because I was one of those who sat on the other side of the chamber in 1975. I am interested to see here my colleague, Senator Withers, who was then the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. I think he will recall, as I do, that it was often said at that time that were the then Government supporters, the senators of the Government party, sitting on the other side of the chamber they would have done exactly the same thing in the same circumstances. I think we have had that explained to us today by the attitudes of Opposition senators to these Bills, particularly the attitude that was expressed by Senator Walsh.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not by Senator Button.

— There we had some difference. Apparently Senator Button had not heard what Senator Walsh said. There was some difference between them because Senator Walsh said the Opposition would take these Bills to the ultimate; the Opposition would expect to see the Bills resulting in a double dissolution of Parliament. He challenged the Government to dissolve Parliament. Over the years the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have both stated time and again their opposition to the blocking of money Bills in the Senate. I think we have heard today that the ALP has an entirely different view when it is sitting on the Opposition benches from the one it had when it was sitting on the Government benches. As far as Government senators are concerned, we have never had a different view with regard to the powers of the Senate and its dealing with legislation. Our attitude is entirely the same. We just wish, as someone has said, that the Senate would put its act together and that everyone would say the same thing at the same time. In particular, I speak to the Australian Democrats. The attitude of the ALP, as expressed by Senator Walsh, Senator Evans and others, is perhaps one worthy of note. To contrast what has been said by them today in particular with an address made to the National Conference of Labor Lawyers by Senator Evans, I think we ought to read his words. In that speech on 3 July, Senator Evans implored his colleagues to resist the temptation to block Supply Bills. In a speech to the Senate on 20 August, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are ample quotes that can be produced of my saying that, as a matter of principle, it is inappropriate for the Senate not only to block Supply but to block money Bills for Budgets.

The honourable senator may take whichever quotes he likes. Senator Evans went on to introduce some spurious distinctions which attempted to amend and qualify the hard and fast ALP principle on the Senate and money Bills. I think it was a weak attempt to explain the about-face of the Labor Party; perhaps the cynicism of the Labor Party's action has now been widely recognised. I think it is interesting to see the enormous advance that has been made in the powers of the Senate in the opinion of Senator Evans since 1975.

Senator Evans told the Labor lawyers that the ALP could 'lose its self-respect and its credibility as a movement'. We can judge whether he is right about that; but, by its own definition, the ALP is not only taking an unprincipled stand but also, as the shadow Attorney-General has said, it is an arguable power that the Senate has. He apparently has some doubts about the constitutional argument that is being put by the Democrats whom he is supporting on this particular vote. The Attorney-General has stated on behalf of the Government that he believes that the Senate does not have the constitutional power to press the request for amendments to a Bill which the Senate cannot amend. I would imagine that the actions of the Labor Party parliamentarians could certainly have been expected by us, particularly those of us who know that they repeatedly oppose money Bills in the Senate. Nobody argues about that. Nobody has argued that there is no power to reject a money Bill in the Senate. We have never argued that. We have never expected any different treatment from that which has been given by the ALP; to use the Democrats words, 'again and again and again and perhaps again'. Labor senators vote against them if they do not like them or if it is politically suitable for them to do so. We have never argued against that. But we cannot help marvelling at the circuitous route of justification which they have used today to explain what apparently has been of some embarrassment to them by the quotes which they all made during 1975.

Turning to the Democrats, perhaps we could say that they were an unknown quantity because they were not members of this House or any other House at that time. But they did make their view abundantly clear. They said on many occasions that they had one abiding principle and one policy. That was, as far as we could make out, because most policies were to be decided by a vote amongst those people who supported them. I think that the one principle that they tried to portray was honesty. The policy that they tried to portray by standing on platforms and waving statutory declarations was that they would never block money Bills. Perhaps in this one debate they have shown that they can throw out what was their one policy and perhaps they have thrown out their one platform. They may have also considerably embarrassed the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Chipp, who on their behalf made very serious commitments with regard to their approach to Bills that would be presented by governments.

The Attorney-General made it clear that the Democrats are in breach of their own statutory declarations, signed by each of them, not to use their voting numbers in such a way as to cause the blocking of money Bills in a manner which would prevent the majority party in the House of Representatives from governing. Their choice was to make those declarations. Nobody asked them to make them. In fact, it is probably part of their inexperience in politics to think that that is essential. A person is elected as a member of parliament and uses his or her judgment when he or she is in the Parliament. He or she is not bound by some other outside authority. People ought to come into the Parliament and use their judgment. Why the Democrats thought they ought to be elected with some divine right and that it would give the people of Australia some assurance in electing them if they signed statutory declarations has always seemed a bit obscure to me. However, that was their way of dealing with the matter. I think we have to say: So much for their honesty, so much for their statutory declarations; go out and tear them up right now.

It is worth recalling how far the Australian Democrats have fallen from their solemn pledge to bring a new purity into Australian politics. We could go back to 1977 and look at their policy statements at that time when they stated:

We solemnly undertake to exercise the power responsibly and constructively. We will not be blockers. We undertake never to exercise that power to block the supply of money to the democratically elected government . . .
That was said in 1977. They were not all elected that time. But, in 1980, Senator Chipp extended this view by saying:
The prime responsibility we have is to assist the Government to carry out its legislative program. We're not in the business of obstructing or disrupting.
We have repeatedly heard Senator Chipp say such things. In 1980, he said:
The Democrats in the Senate would try to help in governing Australia.

That was said on 20 October 1980, exactly one year ago. Compare those statements with what the Democrats have said today. The following statement appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 October 1980. An article in the Australian dated 20 November contained this statement by the Democrats:
We would not wilfully attempt to frustrate or obstruct a government that has won a clear majority of seats.
We expect to be able to help the Fraser Government with its legislative program.

It will be noted that all of these statements were made by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, in the run-up to the last election. They were the solemn promises of those who were going to bring a new purity to government.

The Democrats were making this sort of statement in the course of the election campaign while at the same time reflecting on the honesty of the electioneering material of all other parties, including those who are now joining them from the Opposition benches.

In view of the statements made by the Australian Labor Party and the spokesmen for the Democrats today, it is difficult to see who wins the hypocrisy stakes. All we can say is that they are certainly well suited to each other. Someone said there were no unity tickets between Hayden and somebody else. I would have to say that the courting of the Democrats by the Australian Labor Party is now over. They seem to be united in opposition. One of the speakers for the Democrats said: 'This is not the Democrats moving this. This is a joint effort by the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats'. They are united in opposition. Perhaps the Democrats' honeymoon with the Australian people is now over. Let us see how they get on living together.
In this debate, Senator Mason's statement in the Senate on 26 August has been quoted by the Attorney-General. Let me repeat part of that statement. Senator Mason said:

Listen to this, Senators, it is my bottom line. Those on the Labor side in particular should listen to this. Undesirable though the sales tax increases are, damaging though their impact might be, the consequences of the Senate meddling in or unilaterally rewriting a Budget seem to us too horrifying to contemplate.

They have overcome their horror very quickly. They have very quickly learned that one uses what one of them described as pressure on marginal seats of government members-pressure by groups of people. The comment outside is: 'As groups move in'. It makes one wonder what groups have moved in on the Democrats to get their solemn assurance to tear up their statutory declarations and to go through this tortuous logic that they have used to explain the party's position now and as it was then and to see what sorts of principles they were able to use to overcome their own difficulties. We urge Senator Mason and his colleagues to remember the campaign statements of his party and to look at the election promises that they made the next time they want to embark upon action like this.

One of the honourable senators said that it was not made clear by the Attorney-General what the Government would do when this matter had been regarded as a failure to pass and the three month period had elapsed. It was said that Senator Durack did not say that the Government would bring back the Bill. What Senator Durack said was that, in three months time, it was not in the hands of the Democrats to originate the Bill but he gave a very clear assurance that, at the appropriate time, the Government would deal with the sales tax legislation and it would present to both Houses the Bill that it required to be passed. I do not think that there need be any doubt as to what the Government's approach to that matter would be. What Senator Durack was trying to make clear is that the Democrats have some idea that between now and then it is in their hands to keep the Bill bouncing backwards and forwards between the two Houses. That is just not the case.

There were one or two matters which were raised by honourable senators which I perhaps quickly ought to try to deal with. Senator Jessop mentioned a statement in an article by Geoffrey Sawer in the Canberra Times. I am advised that what was stated in that article does not represent the true position. A provision of the Customs Act prevents officers from being sued when they charge duty in accordance with customs tariff proposals. The essential difference is that Customs have control over goods for both tariff and excise purposes; that no such control for sales tax purposes exists. Perhaps if Senator Jessop seeks further clarification on the matter I could provide it to him.

The honourable senator also referred to an earlier request and to the commitment that I made with regard to items that were regarded by him as being retrospectively affected under other Bills, not the Bill that is now the subject of this debate. (Extension of time granted). I give him an assurance that when the papers are available from the Commissioner and the Comptroller-General they will be the subject of debate concerning matters that were raised by a number of people in relation to the application of changes in the Sales Tax legislation. An opportunity will be provided at some time soon, I hope, for such a discussion to occur.

Senator Martin and Senator Coleman referred to the importation of books and magazines. Senator Coleman referred to a letter written in Perth by the Australian Taxation Office to a Mr G. W. Pidcock. I am advised that that letter did not contain correct advice, and we will have to see that that matter is remedied.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was on 9 October, 11 days ago.

—The advice given to him was not correct. Individual importations of books and magazines may be made free of tax under item 145 of the First Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act provided, firstly, that the value for duty does not exceed $250; secondly, that the tax and duty payable does not exceed $5; and thirdly, that the goods are not part of a bulk order.
—And is it the Government's intention to make that distinction?

— The distinction is provided under item 145. Books are not dutiable. The proposed tax is 2 1/2 per cent. After taking into account the provisions dealing with the sale value of imported goods taxed on entry by Customs, only books, magazines and so on which represent individual importations valued at more than $166 will be subject to sales tax. I suppose that if honourable senators make gifts of that value some problem may arise, but the usual imported periodical magazine would be exempted under item 145.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, I believe, said that the reason we dealt with the Bills in 1975 was because of the economic performance of the Government. Let me put on the record one other fact that was very important at that time. It was that the Whitlam Government thought it could govern without parliament and without Bills if it was not able to have Bills passed. It did not accept that it needed parliamentary approval to do some of the things which governments under our system of parliament are required to do through the parliament. It was also prepared to do a number of other things in a way that was outside of the usual way of doing them, through the Loan Council and a whole range of other things. TALK.START.PARA: —For the last 20 minutes Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has been endeavouring to defend the Government's indefensible position about the introduction of indirect taxation. She has conveniently forgotten that her role is to defend the Government's legislation, not to attack the motives of the Opposition or the other parties in the Senate. She ignores the essential difference between the present and 1974 and 1975, those two momentous years in which the part she and her party played in the double dissolution were quite notorious-as distinct from the motivation of the Opposition, and the majority of the Senate, in respect of the motion that we are required to debate, that is, that the requests be not pressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Guilfoyle is on the public record as setting about with some of her well-known colleagues, within a few brief months of the Whitlam Government coming to office, to bring about the downfall of that Government on any grounds whatever. In 1974, within virtually a year of its coming to office, she played a significant part in affecting adversely the proper management of the economy by the Whitlam Government and helped to bring into play such forces as finally did affect adversely the Budget considerations of that year and those of the following year, 1975. She has not attempted to defend the fact that she conspired on that occasion to undermine the position of the Government, using the majority in this place-including the then minority party, the Democratic Labor Party-for that purpose. That minority party was the motivating force. It joined the Opposition to defeat the Medibank legislation.

She now has the audacity to suggest that it is immoral for another minority party to seek in 1981 to take a position which is identical to that of the Labor Party. Our position is quite clear. We have consistently opposed in the Senate Bills which sought to introduce indirect taxation. That is the Labor Party's view. If, because of our advocacy of that isue and because of public opinion outside the Parliament, which is strongly against the Government's proposals, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine are prepared to join us to become a majority in the Senate I do not believe that that is an immoral position. But I do believe that in 1974 it was immoral to affect the Budget strategy of the Whitlam Government, as indeed it was in 1975 when the Opposition of that time, the Liberal and Country parties, in the Senate failed for more than three months to pass the Appropriation Bills. To suggest, therefore, that the blocking of Supply, which was an essential ingredient of the 1975 fiasco and of the great divisions that occurred in the Australian community as a result, is also the ingredient of this debate is to ignore the essential differences that exist. It is to ignore the fact that the Labor Party has a policy commitment in respect of indirect taxation which is different from that of the Democrats.

Our position in respect of this matter has been consistent. We do not see ourselves as denying the right of the Government to rule, nor are we involved in a conspiracy to bring down the Government, as were Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Withers in 1974 and 1975, when they set about quite deliberately to make untenable the position of a Government with which they disagreed. That Government had been given a mandate in 1972 and again in 1974 and yet the then Opposition set about to cause that Government to fall. In fact, in respect of this legislation, the will of the Senate has been expressed. I believe that we are obliged to reject the motion that has been moved by Senator Durack. Under Standing Order 256 half a dozen options are available to the Senate. The Government has seen fit to move only one of those propositions. That is one which asks the Senate to rescind its previous position and ignore public opinion. The Labor Party is being asked to ignore its policy commitment concerning indirect taxation. The Democrats are being asked to take the same position as that taken by the Government which is notoriously known as a government of broken promises. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has the gall to suggest that it is the Democrats who should be on trial because of some statutory declaration they may have signed when just 13 months ago the Government gave a commitment that it would not introduce a value added tax, that it would not introduce a commodity tax and that it would not increase indirect taxation. Even as late as May of this year the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is on the public record as having said that the Government would not consider the introduction of indirect taxation unless it gave a comparable cut in personal income tax. Of course, that is not involved here. It is this Government that is breaking its word to the electorate; it is this Government that has no mandate in respect of this legislation.

Of course, this afternoon we were subjected to a specious argument by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). It was not a legal argument, although the Attorney-General tried to trade it off as one. It was not even a moral argument because he does not have an argument. He was really asking the Senate not to make a political decision in respect of the matter that is before the Committee, that the request be not pressed. The Committee, of course, has indicated that it is not impressed with the Government's attitude on this matter. The Government is budgeting for a $1.5 billion surplus. In order to allow a capital inflow of some $7 billion from overseas, allegedly for the purpose of strengthening our economy, this Government quite cynically and quite carefully has designed a Budget that will take $1.5 billion out of the domestic economy.

The amount of sales tax to be levied on the necessities of life represents a small part of the Budget-and in no way will affect the basic position of the Budget itself. If this legislation is not passed because the view of the Senate is finally supported in the other place, very little difference will be made to the integrity of the 1981-82 Budget. It will not make that much difference in respect of Budget income and expenditure. But it will make a big difference to the living standards of average Australians who see that the Government's move does not have the support of the Senate and it certainly does not have the support of the Australian electorate.

Absolutely no arguments have been put forward by any of the three Government speakers who took part in the debate this afternoon. Senator Jessop and Senator Martin had some misgivings about the legislation. We know that considerable misgivings were expressed in the Government parties' room about the sales tax proposals. If there are such misgivings in the Government parties, how wrong it is to suggest that the Australian Labor Party or the other sections of the Senate that make up a temporary majority on this issue have some ulterior motive.

Senators are not prepared to somersault on this matter. At least I can say on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that we will certainly not change our mind. Our well known total opposition to any form of indirect taxation is set out in our policy and platform. We believe that that is the view of the Australian electorate. The Government has produced no evidence-certainly the Minister for Finance at the table has produced no evidence-that would suggest that the Labor Party ought in some way or other, to be persuaded to change its view and pass this piece of legislation. I think it is a weakness on the Government's part that it has not been able to prove conclusively that the request that has been made to us by the Attorney-General ought to be supported. Therefore, one would expect that the Committee would maintain the position it has held since this matter became public in the Budget of August this year. I trust that the Senate will continue to maintain that view right to the point of defeating the legislation.
