TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement concerning the selection of Australia's new tactical fighter and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the substance of the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Government has selected, as Australia's new tactical fighter, the F/A-18, manufactured by the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation of the United States of America.
In April 1979, I said to the Parliament that our strategic and geographic circumstances differ in many respects from those of the countries for which the contending aircraft were primarily designed.

If our force is called upon to defend this country or its interests, it may have to do so alone, not as part of a larger allied force having the range of capabilities possible with a mixture of aircraft.

We therefore sought an aircraft versatile in several roles, against both air and surface targets, in all weather conditions. We could not favour an aircraft because of its excellence in any one particular quality.

In air combat, our fighters are likely to have to operate over and beyond our vast Northern regions without the extensive and close control available in the European environment. Hostile surface forces would usually have to cross large expanses of water.

Australia's tactical fighter therefore requires long range and endurance to be able to seek out its targets at a distance. It requires a comprehensive array of air-to-air and air-to-surface weapons necessary to engage them.

The nature of our land is such that we must be able to deploy our tactical fighter force at short notice, over long distances, into bare bases, and to operate there supported by extended air re-supply links.
The aircraft we sought therefore had to be maintainable with the minimum of front line support equipment. It had to have superior qualities of reliability and operational availability.

We also sought minimal peacetime training losses of aircraft and pilots. Because the aircraft chosen must see us through the next twenty years or more, we sought the potential to accommodate the improved weapons and other systems that will undoubtedly emerge during its long life span.
These are the operational factors that bore on the selection-a selection which, to a large extent, will determine the shape of the RAAF into the next century.

We had to choose between two magnificent aircraft-the F/A-18 and the General Dynamics F-16. Both in their different ways are splendidly impressive and capable machines. However, it has become clear that, in relation to the operational factors I have just indicated, the F/A-18 will be better suited to our needs.

The F/A-18 has been developed from the outset as a multi-role aircraft, with all-weather, air-to-air and air-to-surface missiles, and all-weather navigation and weapons targeting systems. These systems give it unparalleled flexibility.

Because it was designed to operate from aircraft carriers, reliability and ease of maintenance were essential elements of the specification of the F/A-18. The testing program has established confidence that these objectives-and from them a very high level of availability-will be achieved.

The F/A-18 is well suited to deployment and operation from forward bases because it requires relatively little airfield support and test equipment. It is well suited to our operating, deployment and maintenance requirements.
It has good potential for adding improved weapons and other systems as these become available. It has features which strongly support the pilot in the efficient and safe prosecution of his mission.
Finally, my advisers are unanimous in their advice that, principally because of its twin engines, the F/A-18 offers a clear prospect of fewer losses throughout its operating life.

Since the Government deferred the selection last year, teams of RAAF and civilian officers have re-examined and refined their assessments of the two contending aircraft. In their endeavours they have had, throughout, the unstinting assistance of the U.S. departments of defence, navy and air force and of the two prime manufacturers and their sub-contractors. The government is deeply appreciative of the support given.

My senior advisers-and in particular, the chief defence scientist and the chief of air force technical services-now see no substantial technical obstacles to the development of either aircraft in the form that we have sought.

The aerodynamic problems evidenced in the F/A-18 have been satisfactorily resolved. The U.S. Department of Defense has now given approval for full production of the aircraft in the air-to-air fighter role. Clearance of additional weapons for the air-to-surface attack role is not due until about this time next year. My advisers are now confident that the outcome will be acceptable, but we will be requiring the U.S. Navy not to place the main contract for our aircraft until this clearance is available.

Sufficient structural fatigue testing has been completed to clear the F/A-18 for its first ten years of operation. Tests necessary to give assurances of a further ten years of life will continue until 1984. Any consequential modifications to achieve this will be known by then.

In the case of the F-16, uncertainties that earlier surrounded the progress of its weapons enhancement program have receded, but nevertheless persists in some respects. Particular doubts have arisen about the F-16's new all-weather targeting and navigation systems-necessary to meet Australia's requirements.

There will be very proper concern too that the cost of such a vast project should be known with confidence. There will be a temptation to turn back to earlier experiences and see them reflected in the future and there can never, of course, be absolute guarantees about a production program which reaches until the end of the decade.
Concerns about cost should be tempered with an understanding of the processes that have contributed and will continue to contribute to our confidence.

In their examination of the two contenders, our evaluation teams have had unconstrained access to all of the material on these aircraft that is available to the U.S. Department of Defense. That organisation has behind it the experience of managing the world's most formidable manufacturing programs.

The review processes available to me have been strengthened by the defence re-organisation of the mid-1970s. Recommendations now flow from a formalised process of examination which consolidates the deliberate judgements of the most senior specialists in all of the relevant skills: scientific, engineering, financial, legal-contractual and more.

It deserves to be said that the professional and technical qualifications of those involved in the new tactical fighter project are second to none. I hope the country will make proper acknowledgement of that fact.

To implement the project, we are making arrangements that will allow this country to place its experts within the U.S. Government's project management team. They will participate in its day-to-day processes.
The Government believes that a program can be implemented that minimises Australia's exposure to the uncertainties of the future and that a decision can and should be made now.
The overall project cost of 75 F/A-18 aircraft is $2430 million in August 1981 prices.

This includes the costs of some configuration changes to meet the RAAF's operational requirements, and the cost of simulators, spares, test equipment, training equipment and the like. It also includes the cost of new buildings and overhaul facilities at RAAF bases and the costs of establishing important support capabilities in Australian industry. A contingency sum has been included where risks remain.
There has been public speculation about the difference in the cost of the alternative F-16 aircraft.

The overall project cost for the F-16 would have been some 7 per cent less than for the F/A-18. However, it is estimated that when we take account of running and support costs and of attrition throughout the life of the aircraft this difference will be substantially reduced.
The F/A-18 costs have grown during development. I cannot rule out further increases. I have said that there could be modifications flowing from structural testing. They are not expected to be costly.
The chief risk appears to be the possibility of reduction in the production rate in the early years of the program, thus increasing production costs.

To contain cost growth, the Government is stipulating that the manufacture of the first of our aircraft should not precede a specified number of aircraft in the U.S. program unless we decide otherwise. In this way, we will secure for Australia the benefit of the continuing testing and development of the aircraft and of early U.S. squadron experience. These and other arrangements too detailed to relate now give us advantages that we have not had in the management of earlier programs.

There will, of course, be cost increases due to world-wide inflationary trends. As it has done in the past for other major equipment acquisitions, the Government will keep the House informed of movements in cost of the project, both up and down, and both real and inflationary, against the base of the August 1981 price levels.

During 1980 I reached with the U.S. Department of Defense very satisfactory arrangements under which the project has been developed and under which the associated Australian industry program will be put into effect and managed. The actual purchase instruments will contain more detailed conditions. My Department has necessarily yet to conclude discussions with the U.S. Departments on a number of matters that relate to the specific aircraft chosen. I will not be agreeing the acceptance of formal purchase documents until a satisfactory position has been reached.

On present planning the RAAF can look forward to receiving its first F/A-18 before the end of 1984. Pilots should begin operational training with them in the second half of 1985. Aircraft should be flowing from Australian production at a rate of three aircraft every two months by the middle of 1986, and deliveries should be completed in 1990.
I turn to the role that the Australian industry will have in the new tactical fighter program.

Establishment of a capability for through-life support in Australia is a fundamental element of the program. The new fighter will be in service with the RAAF well into the next century. Australian industry must command key technologies needed to support it.

Agreement has been reached with the U.S. contractors on work to be carried out on our aircraft in Australia and on an associated export offset program. The added value of the offset work is to be 30 per cent of the imported cost of the program, and there will be compensation provisions if the U.S. contractors fail to honour their commitments.

The corner stone of the Australian industry program will be the final assembly and test of the F/A-18 at the Government Aircraft Factories at Avalon. This will equip Australian engineers and technicians with an intimate understanding of the sophisticated sub-systems of the aircraft. The engines will also be assembled and tested in Australia, at the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation at Melbourne.
Major parts of the aircraft, of its engines and of its electronic and mechanical systems will be manufactured in Australia in order to introduce new technologies we need to support the F/A-18.

To carry out this work many new facilities and items of specialised production and text equipment will be introduced into our factories. This will have a dramatic effect on our skills in many areas-to name but a few: radar, digital electronics, control systems and new super-materials in engines and structures.

Unavoidably the cost of work done in Australia for our own relatively small numbers of aircraft will be greater than those in the U.S. These additional costs are the price we have to pay for the self-reliance we want in the support of our own aircraft. They have been included in the total cost figure I gave earlier.

Included in the costs are investments in tooling, test equipment and machinery, plant and facilities. Much of this investment would be required in any event to support the new tactical fighter in Australia and will have application to other defence programs in the future.

The tactical fighter force project is a major national enterprise. It will involve not only the RAAF, and my department, but a host of contractors and sub-contractors in Australia's defence-related industry.
It will provide us with a central element of the forces needed to defend our nation's security.
It will develop our technological and industrial capacity in an area critical to our defences but also important on a wider national basis.

The presence, in this part of the world of repair and overhaul facilities for the F/A-18 will be a significant military advantage also for our ANZUS ally, the United States. The benefits of inter-operability and common support will be of value to both nations.

We have not entered upon this large and testing program without carefully weighing the risks. I am confident that we have in being a work force with the skills necessary to meet this demanding challenge.

It would be difficult for anyone not close to it to conceive the scale of the task involved in the tactical fighter evaluation and its industry progam. Those who have carried it through have worked with extreme dedication. I express my appreciation of their efforts.
I ask the House to give this undertaking its complete support.
I now inform the House of a further major decision concerning the RAAF's long range maritime patrol force.

Instead of the modernisation announced last year of the older P3B Orion aircraft, the government has decided to sell the P3Bs and to acquire ten more P3Cs subject to satisfactory contractural negotiations. The cost of proceeding this way is estimated at $240m. It involves a premium of some $50m which, in the government's view, is worth paying.

We shall avoid the major disruption of the maritime patrol force involved in a major modernisation of half of its aircraft. The P3Bs when modernised, would have had a life expectancy of less than half of that of the existing P3Cs, which will not need replacement until beyond the end of the century.

The new aircraft will be equipped, as are the ten P3Cs we now operate, for the harpoon anti-ship missile and the Australian-developed Barra anti-submarine sonobuoy system. I expect the first aircraft to be delivered in 1985 and the entire squadron to be re-equipped by 1987.

Honourable members will recall the government's decision last year concerning the follow-on destroyer project. I announced the intention to build two FFG-type ships at Williamstown Naval Dockyard, subject to satisfactory resolution of a number of problems affecting productivity there.

I expect to be dealing shortly with recommendations about the future of that dockyard. Meantime, the government has decided to order long-lead items from the United States for the construction in due course of the first vessel.

In making this decision now, we make it possible-should the problems that have beset Williamstown in recent years be resolved-to begin construction of the ship there next year. If there is no improvement-and I want this to be clear-we shall have to look to construction elsewhere. An order of long-lead items for a follow-on destroyer involves no commitment to build at Williamstown.

Our plans for the development of the Australian-designed minehunting catamaran are proceeding and tenders for construction of two prototypes are presently being evaluated. But to complement these minehunters we need to be able to sweep mines.

I confirm to honourable members that the British hunt class is under consideration for this role. We have the opportunity to acquire vessels ordered originally for the Royal Navy. We are investigating the acquisition of two vessels with an option on a third. The decision will be made later in this financial year.

In September 1980, I informed the house that Government had decided to replace HMAS Melbourne with a purpose-designed ship to be equipped with helicopters for anti-submarine warfare and to have the potential to operate short take-off and vertical-landing aircraft. I said also that further definition of the details of the new carrier would be completed in the next financial year. These investigations are proceeding and, as honourable members will be aware, have been widened to include an examination of the offer from Britain of an invincible class ship.

I shall make a statement in due course on the new carrier. I also hope to be able to inform the House of the Government's intentions for the further modernisation of our three DDG guided missile destroyers.
There have been a number of recent decisions regarding new equipment for the army.

Equipment operated by the army is characterised by quantity and diversity. Few items attract the public spotlight sometimes focussed on the ships and aircraft of the other services. The Budget makes provision for a range of new equipment for the army. Several decisions, for example those relating to the acquisition of some 2235 new trucks of two types, totalling over $150 million, have been the subject recently of separate announcements.
However, I want to mention three projects today. All three will be implemented in such a way as significantly to enhance Australian self-reliance.

The first is the establishment of production capability and the initial manufacture by Australian industry of a new 105mm artillery weapon of an overseas design. On the successful completion of this pre-production phase, the weapon and its ammunition will be ordered in substanital numbers. It will be considerably more capable than our existing 105mm guns.
I shall be releasing further details shortly.

The second, project raven, aims to provide the army with a new family of single-channel portable tactical radios. The government has decided to allocate resources to the development of the high frequency component of the radios by Australian industry, and to preparations for its subsequent production. This project will transfer design skills and technology to Australia that will place this country in the forefront of world developments in the field.

Thirdly I inform the House of the Government's decision to spend over a period of several years, some $80m on expanding the army's operations reserve of ammunition. Some $60m of this will be spent on manufacturing ammunition in Australia, including types of ammunition not previously produced here.

The development, within industry, of capacities needed to supply and support the defence force, and thus to increase our self-reliance, continues to have a high place in the Government's considerations.
Participation by Australian industry in the provision of defence equipment is one important means of implementing this policy. Another involves direct expenditure on facilities in industry.

The 1981-82 Budget makes provision for an approximate doubling of expenditure (to $39.5 million) on new plant and facilities in the aircraft industry and munitions factories. Major facilities being established include a nitro-glycerine plant at Mulwala, New South Wales; a composite material and bonding workshop at the Government Aircraft Factories, Melbourne, and a heavy shell-forging facility at the ordnance factory at Maribyrnong in Victoria. We are also expanding the existing facilities for manufacturing barra sonobuoys in Sydney and for the production of micro-electronic components in the plants of several commercial defence contractors.
Virtually all defence activities depend on infrastructure-bases, barracks, dockyards, workshops, stores, training establishments, communication stations and a variety of other facilities.
In 1981-82, $179 million is to be spent on capital facilities for defence-much of it in the north and west of Australia.
This month, a new ammunition depot was opened at HMAS Stirling, near Perth: and a fuel storage capacity is being provided there.
During 1982, the new patrol boat bases at Cairns and Darwin will be completed.

Improvements will be made to the RAAF airfield at Darwin, in preparation for the basing there of a tactical fighter squadron, and to the airfield at Learmonth. Work is continuing on the design of the proposed airfield at Derby.
The second major stage in the modernisation of Garden Island Dockyard, Sydney, will be commenced this year.

The RAAF's operational flexibility will be improved by additional fuel storage capacity at Tindal, Williamtown, Amberley and Richmond. Planning will continue for facilities at Williamtown to support the new tactical fighter. The Government proposes to improve the airfield at Woomera so that it can be used more intensively by all the types of aircraft operated by the defence force.

The increasing technical sophistication of modern defence equipment requires additional trained manpower. Accommodation to cope with extra trainees is to be provided at RAAF technical training schools at Wagga and Laverton. Plans are also being developed for new training facilities at the RAAF School of Navigation at East Sale.
New works will be undertaken at the army's armoured centre at Puckapunyal, and improved facilities for training army officers for higher command are proposed at the Army Staff College at Queenscliff.
It is also proposed to construct a new building at the materials research laboratory at Maribyrnong to support advanced research and development in laser technology.

An important element of the defence infrastructure is housing for servicemen. Over 200 houses will be provided in Townsville, for members of the operational deployment force and 95 houses at Liverpool/Holsworthy, for members of the army's 1st task force. Some service houses which are below acceptable standards, such as at the army establishment at Woodside, South Australia, will be replaced.
The measures and decisions that I have so far been describing-all involving capital investments-are mostly directed towards longer term objectives.

Some-especially in the areas of industrial capacity and defence facilities development-are specifically tailored to allow us to shift more easily to a higher level of defence preparedness should that later be judged necessary.

Time will not permit me today to describe the multiplicity of other activities being undertaken with a similar purpose. Many of them are not especially glamorous and do not attract much attention. They concern infrastructure and manpower, especially in areas where there are long lead times for the acquisition of skills. They are, however, very important for their effect on our expansion capabilities for the future.

So too are the underlying planning priorities that require each new initiative to provide in Australia, managed by Australians, arrangements that will allow us to use and support our weapons in an independent force: The training schools, the ''software'' facilities, the computer-managed stock control systems, the command, control and communications systems, the joint staff training and the hundreds of other activities that could stand us in good stead should we need greater military strength and have to fight alone.
As well as these longer-term measures, we are lifting our levels of defence preparedness in the shorter term by a number of means. I can touch briefly, today, on but a few.

The activity of the defence force has been stepped up-and this will continue under provisions in the present Budget. In particular, maritime operations in our northern and western ocean approaches have been increased.
Over the past three years there has been a significant and sustained increase in combined and joint exercises. Some 53 were conducted in 1979-80, 80 in 1980-81 and 81 are planned for 1981-82.

I should make here a brief reference to exercise Kangaroo 81, currently being conducted off the east coast of Australia and in the Shoalwater Bay training area. The exercise is the fourth in the series and some 25 ships, 100 aircraft and 20,000 ANZUS and British military personnel are involved. Kangaroo 81 is a complex and ambitious exercise which has been developed from previous exercises in the series. It will develop further our-that is, Australia's-operational doctrine and procedures for the command and control of joint and combined operations in our region.

We are steadily increasing the number of regular defence force personnel to support increases in activities and the manning of new equipment and to expand the training base. The estimates provide for service manpower increases of over one thousand above the level at 30 June 1981.

The army reserve has been expanded in less than a year to reach very close to the Government's target figure of 30,000. At 1 July the figure was 29,822. I want to pay tribute to the young people of this country and also to the work of those responsible for the massive effort that was involved.
The task remains to round off this achievement, and to consolidate it. Appropriate provisions have been built into the defence estimates, including provision for additional modern equipment.

I should also inform the House that the operational deployment force or ODF in Townsville has received the additional personnel necessary to bring it to full operations strength, including integral combat, administrative and logistic support elements.

The raison d'etre for the ODF is to provide the first land element of the defence force deployed in a contingency. It has completed its re-equipment program and is now organised to be transportable in the aircraft of the Australian defence force. Provisions have been built into the defence estimates for its continued development and maintanance at a high state of readiness.

The cost of the defence program on which we have embarked will be very heavy. It will impact on every Australian. It has been necessary this year to make the largest peacetime allocation (in real terms) to defence ever made in the history of this nation-and at a time of budgetry restraint and continued prosecution of the war against inflation.
The effort will have to be sustained.

Over the period since 1976 estimated real growth in defence outlays has already averaged slightly more than three per cent per annum, as compared with an annual average real growth in total Commonwealth Budget outlays, over the same period, of slightly more than one per cent.
The Prime Minister announced early in 1980 that the Government had decided upon greater allocations of resources to our defences.

Allocation of resources is made in the context of the Budget each year. However, the Government understands the need for a stable planning base and in March 1980 I announced details of the planning basis for the five years 1980-85. It involved:
Defence spending of some $17,600 million (in August 1979 prices) over the five years;
An average annual growth rate of about 7 per cent;
Spending to increase to around 3 per cent of GDP by 1984-85;
An increase, over the five years, in the proportion of expenditure on capital investment rising to over 25 per cent by 1984-85.
The 1980-81 Budget provided for real growth in defence outlay of about 7 per cent including a provision towards the purchase of the new tactical fighters.
In the event, a number of factors, of which the most substantial was deferral of the decision on the fighter, resulted in a somewhat lower real growth of about 5.6 per cent in 1980-81.

The deferral last year of the decision on the fighter, together with difficulties in progressing other capital equipment projects, will also affect the rate of increase in expenditure in the immediate future.
Thus in 1981-82, the Budget provides $4,112 million for defence outlay, a real increase of 5.3 per cent over 1980-81.

However, the obligations already entered into, mainly for capital equipment and facilities, now total $2580 million. These obligations will be further increased by the very large commitments soon to be entered into for the new tactical fighter and for other major equipment projects.

Expenditure in the next several years against these obligations will plainly require the allocation of resources to defence to continue to increase. If I may give but one example, on present projections a little less than $100 million will be required for the new fighters in 1981-82. The figure will increase to $400 million per year in 1983-84. That is comparable with what we spent in 1978-79 on all capital equipment.
The Government is resolved to sustain the long haul begun in February last year to lift our defence preparedness into a new plateau.
What I have announced represents a significant burden to the Australian taxpayer. I an thoroughly conscious of that fact.

Our circumstances and our responsibilities have changed greatly during the course of the past ten years. We have a clear commitment to fend for ourselves and to contribute to stability in our immediate region.
I find myself in complete agreement with that philosophic view which contends that men and women who have a preference for the estate of liberty must carry with grace the burden of protecting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as the Government is in something of a shambles on matters organisational this evening, as has been demonstrated, and just as it lacks credibility in that respect, it is clear that the Government has no credibility at all on defence matters. This is because of a very long history of broken promises in this area. Back in 1976, it announced a five-year program involving a 5 per cent increase in expenditure each year in real terms. In actual fact, the percentage increase has been something less than 4 per cent. Again, in that period, it was to dedicate 24 per cent of the total defence budget for spending on capital equipment but in actual fact the figure has been only approximately 15 per cent. In its most recent commitment, the Government has stated a concern to ensure something like 7 per cent in real increases each year for the next five years. But it has already failed to meet that commitment this financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I guess that the problem from now on will not be so much a failure to meet stated commitments of this kind. The problem in the future is likely to be not so much one of a defence budget limping behind targeted expenditure, as has been the case now for the last five years, but rather, in terms of the aftermath of today's statement, one of expenditure exploding out of control in a situation where there has been no substantial cost benefit analysis and an area in which a number of questions still remain unresolved so far as major procurement provisions are concerned. The decision announced today to order the FA18 over its immediate competitor the F16 is a gamble which highlights the parlous defence position we are now in. As is evident from the terms of the ministerial statement, the decision has been made without any convincing knowledge of the costs finally of the aircraft, without any convincing knowledge of the aircraft's perfomance-for example, the likely number of losses: That is to say, the attrition rate-and without any convincing assessment, most importantly, of Australia's real strategic environment and defence needs.

In all these respects we are completely in the dark. We are no less in the dark as a result of the ministerial statement than we were before Mr Killen rose to his feet to deliver it. Insofar as the cost question is concerned, the Government has not been able to produce any guarantees that we will not witness a repeat of the dreadful saga of the F-111. Indeed the elements are there for such a saga to be repeated. In the first place, the United States Government's foreign military sales policy requires that a purchaser pay the full commercial price at the time of delivery. Indeed, just yesterday, the Australian Financial Review reported the United States Deputy Secretary of Defence, Mr Frank Carlucci, as having assured a congressman recently that the Australian price for the FA18 would be at least as much as the United States Navy would pay for its FA18. He said that the United States will use:
'. . . audit assistance during the negotiation process to assure there are no subsidies and that any Australian unique costs will be charged totally to the Australian Government'.
He also told the congressman that the estimated total program unit cost is:
far in excess of the cost cited by the Australian press.

That latter comment of course is particularly important and certainly lends support to Labor's suspicions that we are with this particular transaction at this stage still buying a pig in a poke. Secondly, it is the case that the estimated cost of the FA18 is based on a production run of over 1,360 planes. Naturally, economies of scale in this respect are most important. Should the total number of planes be reduced, as happened in the case of the F-111, the cost of the planes that Australia buys will naturally escalate. It was reported in this morning's Australian Financial Review that the Republican Chairman of the United States Senate Appropriations Committee, Senator Mark Hatfield, called for the Reagan Administration to cancel the FA18 program altogether. He dubbed the program as being, among other things, 'of dubious military value, and in many cases riddled with costs overruns'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Republican.

—He is a Republican. He is very close to the Reagan Administration. He knows, far better than I or someone like Senator Teague, exactly what is the thinking of the US Administration, the highest political level on these matters. The fact that those sorts of things can be said as recently as the last day or so surely makes it very doubtful indeed that we can be guaranteed as to the production run of these aeroplanes. While it certainly does not seem reasonable to make the supposition at this stage that the program will be scrapped altogether, it could very easily be scaled down. Again we have the example of the quotation on the record from US Navy Secretary Lehman who, on 20 August this year, warned that the United States Navy might cancel its FA18s if there were any further significant cost increases. He is quoted as saying somewhere: 'We may be forced to shop elsewhere'. Naturally there are unresolved questions about the FA18s. What makes those unresolved questions and the costing of them so important is the sheer magnitude of the dollars and cents involved and the competing uses, obviously, to which those dollars could be directed at the moment. The estimate by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) in this statement of an overall cost at the moment of $2,430m appears to be, even at this stage, verifiably wrong. In December 1980 the United States estimate was $24m per aeroplane. If there is added to that what seems to be the going rule of thumb calculation-a 50 per cent sum for spares, training and so on-the figure comes out at a total $2,700m, compared to the figure of a little over $2,400m announced today. The figures start to escalate wildly once one gets into the future in inflationary dollars rather than present day dollars, but the United States Navy says that the cost per aeroplane in 1982 will be around $27.7m and that in 1984 it will be around $30m. Adding the 50 per cent component for spares and the like, we are talking already of a total cost of around $3.3 billion by 1984. That is substantially in excess of the dollar figures mentioned in the Minister's statement. This is of obvious significance to the Government's capacity to deliver not only in the defence area but also across the whole budgetary spectrum.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also to be noted that the major competitors of the FA18 have been prepared to offer the Australian Government a contract which involves a fixed price for the aeroplanes, and a fixed escalation factor for inflation, neither of which seems to be built into the present calculations for the FA18. In addition, the F16 and the Panavia Tornado have been in production, as we all know, for much longer than the FA18 and the likelihood of cost escalation in respect of those two aeroplanes at this stage must now be regarded as far less. The cost of the FA18 has already risen by 20 per cent in real terms, not inflationary terms, over the life of the program. There are very real and natural fears in many responsible quarters that that escalation could continue much further. On the other hand, there is no doubt that the performance and the potential of the FA18 are great indeed.

I certainly do not claim to be more capable than any of my colleagues of making any substantially effective technical evaluation of the competing merits of these aeroplanes, but clearly from everything we have been told, everything objectively on the public record, it is an aeroplane with a very substantial number of plusses. At present, as we know, only 12 to 15 of them are actually flying. They are not fully operational in any air force in the world. The Canadians, who are first in line in this respect, are already becoming visibly restive. Delays are developing in the program and some aspects of that program are now running two years behind even more recent estimates. The Minister simply has not provided any hard evidence of the kind that I think can reasonably be demanded of him and of the Government when expenditure of this magnitude is being contemplated that all the kinks involved have been or will be capable of being ironed out.

On the other hand, there is a precedent for the Defence Department's procurement advisors to go for state of the art technology, as it is described, without adequately considering the practical issues at stake, and with disastrous results. As recently as 8 September this year there was an article by John Stackhouse in the Bulletin entitled 'Defence Department in $200m Contract Fiasco'. This article, concerning the way the new defence communications system had gone off the rails, said that the key group of Defence Department experts had become hooked on what was described as the 'technical elegance' of the integrated switching system. They regarded technical elegance, to the exclusion of all else, as the paramount consideration. We hope simply that with precedents of that kind littering the Defence Department's landscape within recent memory, we are not confronted with a similar passionate pro-occupation with state of the art technical elegance to the exclusion of other considerations as the finally decisive consideration behind the choice of this aircraft.

Perhaps more significantly than all of that, we have not been provided with the strategic basis on which the decision to purchase these fighters was made. In the whole of my time in this Parliament I have never heard any full scale debate on what Australia's strategic situation actually is and what our defence needs really are. There is certainly nothing in the Minister's statement today which even begins to answer these questions and there is nothing in any of his other statements that I have read over recent years. For example, on what basis did we decide to increase the number of front line fighters from 25 to 75? What sort of enemy do we believe we will be fighting during the potential lifetime of these aircraft? In what circumstances do we believe that the aircraft will be used or might be used? What are the kinds of contingencies against which we are planning by the introduction of these aircraft?

There has not been any reassessment of which I am aware, certainly not one made publicly available, of the whole tactical fighter force program following, for example, such events of crucial international significance as the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. The strategic basis document simply does not address itself to these kinds of fundamental defence questions. It says nothing about our optimal defence posture, whether it should be essentially maritime, ground, unconventional, nuclear or whatever. The language of that document is grey and qualified and it can be used, as it seems to have been used by the Department of Defence, to justify the purchase of any equipment that for extrinsic reasons the key officers of the Department are minded to get behind.

With our obviously limited resources it does not seem to be especially desirable that all three Services should be striving after and attaining superior or state of the art-so described-capabilities. Obviously we must have the capacity to strike out from the Australian continent and, equally obviously, we need to have the ability to mobilise our resources within the continent. Just as there is a need for mobility of this kind, there is a need for industrial capacity to lie behind it. In this respect the Government decision to sell the ordnance factory at Bendigo to private enterprise is a nonsensical demonstration of the Government's failure to commit itself to serious long term planning.

There does need to be established a far more cost-effective approach to defence of the kind involved in the purchase of PC3 Orions or submarines, which are by all accounts very cost-effective bits of equipment and weaponry, in defending Australian territory. There does seem to be a need, which is generally accepted, for more cost-effective purchases along the lines of surface vessels of frigate standard, and tactical fighters that do not necessarily involve the kind of extravagant and, on the face of it, state of the art technology that is being striven after here with the FA18s.

All of these are questions upon which reasonable men and women can undoubtedly differ. They are all matters which it is ridiculously superficial in many ways to be endeavouring to touch upon, even in this preliminary reply to the Minister's statement. The only reason that makes me mention these matters is that there is little evidence on the face of this statement, last year's major defence statement or the one which was made back in 1976, that the Government has seriously thought about these issues. If it has thought about them it has not shared its understanding and its thinking with the Parliament and the Australian people. Instead it simply seems to be enamoured of the kind of knee-jerk option, the knee-jerk approach that throwing money at defence-it might almost be described as the Reagan approach-will solve our problems.

The Minister's statement describes the defence allocation that is proposed with the purchase of the FA18s and the other equipment as set out, as being the largest peace time allocation to defence in real terms that has ever been made in the history of our nation. Those of us who have seen this Government time and time again skate away from its undertakings on defence will believe all this when we see it. More disturbingly, the increased spending is not accompanied by any indication on the Government's part of what its defence priorities and actual aims are. Some of the planes which the Government was offered were better dog-fighters. Others were better at interception. We have not been told-if indeed it has ever been a matter for Government decision-what criteria are ultimately appropriate to judge these alternative and other relevant skills. The only thing that does appear to have happened in this regard is that the Department of Defence used some kind of pea and thimble trick-the technical details of which remain undisclosed-to eliminate, firstly, the Panavia Tornado by saying that we needed to have a dog-fighter and then, secondly, eliminating the Mirage and the F16 on the basis that a strike capacity was more important in Australia than a dog-fighting capacity.

In recent years we have witnessed a history in the Department of Defence of neglect and bungling. On the one hand, purchases have been delayed. It has been suggested that already we are in difficult circumstances as a result of that. We know that the Mirage is now subject to severe and worsening fatigue problems and that its avionics are now museum pieces. It has been alleged that in some years-in the middle of the 1980s-we will be lacking any tactical air defence worthy of that name. On the other hand, we are not persuaded that the issues are any nearer to resolution as a result of the Government's delay. We believe the decision should not be made on these issues until all the various matters to which I have referred tonight-necessarily superficially and only in outline-are resolved. The Australian public cannot be expected to dig ever deeper to support a massive program of expenditure of this kind unless it can be satisfied, and unless we in this Parliament can be satisfied, that the issues of cost and strategic effectiveness-above all else, strategic effectiveness-have been resolved.

Alternative aircraft are still available to the Government. The Australian Labor Party is not in a position to endorse one of these options rather than the other. At least it is obvious that there are still serious alternatives. It remains a very real question as to whether the decision should have been made at the time despite all the delays in which the Government has engaged in the past in it re-equipment program. Nonetheless, this is the big one and this is the one on which the Government ought not to have moved in the direction it has moved with the FA18 unless it was absolutely sure that in every critical respect it was overwhelmingly superior to its competitors. It is not obvious even now that that is so. It is not obvious from the terms of the ministerial statement.

In respect of the F16 aircraft, the cost estimate at $1,027m for the planes and 50 per cent for the spares, training and so on component, makes an all-up cost of $1,541m. That is half the cost of the FA18, which is not the percentage as suggested in the ministerial statement. At this sort of cost we could buy, it seems, something like twice as many F16s. The comparative attrition rate becomes far less significant under those circumstances than it has been claimed to be. It seems to be generally accepted that the aircraft has a formidable strike capacity. As a result of its undergoing the multinational staged improvement program, it will soon meet all the demands that the Royal Australian Air Force may reasonably make of it. The Panavia Tornado remains a viable contender in the event that the FA18 proves to go down the plug hole either in terms of utterly unacceptable cost escalation or for some other reason.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has received a telex to the effect that the whole program could be achieved for a sum of $1,508m at January 1981 prices. That is a fly-away price of something like only $15m per plane. As we all know, that is a technologically advanced aircraft. The comparative cost of that aircraft has certainly been reduced vis a vis its competitors since the Department of Defence scrubbed that proposal at the end of 1978. We are told by the experts that in its F2 version it is not such a good dog-fighter as its competitors, but it is an effective interceptor which, it can be argued, is more important in Australia's circumstances.

The FA18 may still prove to be a better plane by all the relevant criteria that again I have been trying to spell out. As things stand, we can scarcely be assured that this is so. We can scarcely be confident in being asked, as a Parliament, to approve and endorse this purchase without more information and more satisfaction being given along the lines that I have described. The Government has approved in this statement a total expenditure of something like $10 billion, which is equivalent to 16 years of expenditure at the present rate. There is no indication in this statement that this has been done on an adequate basis which will prove defensible as the years roll on. There is no basis for supposing, on the terms of the ministerial statement, that our chickens simply will not come home to roost in the way they have so often and unfortunately done in the defence area in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree with a good deal of what Senator Evans said at the beginning of his speech, which is not entirely unusual. I wonder whether he could have perceived at last that the coin may have dropped into the machine, as far as the Government is concerned, and that the Government may be beginning to appreciate in some dim sort of way that we may have to defend this country ourselves at some time and it is important that we should think about how we will do it, especially in conditions where we know, regarding this episode of a 17-year-old drama about a fighter replacement, how long it takes the Government to get around to obtaining this sort of material. I think the Government is now beginning to realise that there is not automatically a big powerful daddy who will hold our hand and lead us on safely through the perils of this world. The decision to buy 75 highly sophisticated aircraft is a practical expression, perhaps the first practical expression, of this new view. It is expressed in the first page of the statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) where he says:

SPEECH.PARA: If our force is called upon to defend this country or its interests, it may have to do so alone, not as part of a larger allied force having the range of capabilities possible with a mixture of aircraft. We therefore sought an aircraft versatile in several roles, against both air and surface targets, in all weather conditions. We could not favour an aircraft because of its excellence in any one particular quality.

I was heartened to hear those remarks because now, in spite of its great cost, we have in the F18 Hornet a weapon which is designed to defend this country, in combination with other forces-I will go on to that a little later-against any kind of attack or invasion on it. This is definitely a change in the Government's views as expressed over the last few years, especially in the naval area. I have complained before about the pop-gun Navy and the way we have built a first class small warship of the Fremantle class. I have been aboard HMAS Fremantle, have looked at her and have discussed the ship with various people who know much more about it than I do. They say that it is a first class small warship.

We have given the ship a main armament of one World War II type Bofors gun. I am assured that if the vessel is attacking upwind in a slight chop, that gun cannot even be fired to put a shot across the bows of a Taiwanese fishing boat. Those Bofors guns at one stage many decades ago had a proper place on the flight decks of strike aircraft carriers. They certainly have no place on the foredecks of our rather expensive small warships. They are patrol vessels of a type used everywhere else in the world to carry missiles as missile attack ships. Of course, our ships should be used in that role too.

Now we have hope that the Government possibly is getting its eye on the ball. We hope that it will now be consistent, that it will tidy up the Fremantle class and make sure that later ships in that class which are built in Cairns have the potential to be converted to missile capability quickly. I know they have the space within them. I have had pointed out to me the actual space where hardware could go. But it is necessary, as the ships are built, for them to have the wiring channels and so on in them. Of course, it would be far better if they were organised for a ship to ship missile like Exocet right from the start. I have hopes that the Government might even do that.

Let us forget all this nonsense about a short-deck aircraft carrier at great expense and with some vague anti-submarine function which it could not even perform very well. It could not perform it very well up to the time when it was knocked off by a much faster attack submarine or something of that sort. There is no way in the world that the World War II idea of having a short deck aircraft carrier will work any more. Goodness knows what it is going to do, anyway. It would need a complex screeen of other vessels around it to try to protect it.

I cannot understand why we are going to the enormous expense of creating this monster which will have jump-jet aircraft on it. Their main idea-this is certainly the case with the British class-will be to defend the carrier itself. If there were not a carrier, there would not even be a need for them. Helicopters would be needed on it which are not as suitable or efficient as many other airborne systems of anti-submarine surveillance and attack which we have. Where the helicopters go after the carrier has sunk the naval planners have not deigned to tell us yet. It is a very interesting question. Presumably they will go into the sea with the crew of the carrier and everything else. It is a disastrous thought. It would be an absolute disaster of the first magnitude and it should be recognised as such.

Let us instead get the naval equivalent of the F18 aircraft which is available to us. By that I mean the fast missile attack ships, preferably hydrofoils, which have an efficient co-ordinated missile capability-harpoon missiles. It is a fact that there are such ships, which I have mentioned before-the Pegasus class-although I am by no means sold on that vessel. At least it carries eight harpoon missiles on light-weight launchers. A group of those in fact would be the naval equivalent of the F18. They would carry out the same kind of role. Indeed, they could work in with what we are aiming at with the F18s.

If the Government wants the F18, we go along with that. They are terribly expensive. We could argue all night about whether we should have that aircraft or something else. If we are to get that aircraft I think we are at least working along the right lines. But for heaven's sake, let us also try to get our naval capability enhanced and get whatever else we might be able to get so that the Navy can fulfil the same role as other forces. We might even consider repairing and patching up a few Leopard tanks and moving them from Puckapunyal to Darwin. It would take a long time to get them there. We will not be able to get them there when an enemy is attacking us. That is a place for a tank force, if it is to be anywhere. It should be placed where it can attack an invader.

Let us look at the F18. The Government has selected it on the ground of versatility. It believes the attrition rate will be lower for the FA18, presumably on the basis that it has two engines. That is a respectable argument. We agree with it. The Canadians came to a similar conclusion and they chose the F18 for the same reason. It is almost impossible to assess what the cost will be in the long run. One can pick any figure out of the air up to $4 billion by the time we eventually get these aircraft. If we want to go into the defence business and we want to be able to defend the country, that is part of the cost.

I want to raise one matter at this stage. There was a report in the Australian this morning that the Government at long last apparently will go ahead with the jet trainer. It has announced the formation of a new company, the Australian Aircraft Consortium, to be owned equally by the Government Aircraft Factory, Hawker de Havilland Australia and the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation. The article states that the turbo-prop trainer which has been designed in Australia:
. . . will be the first aircraft for more than 20 years to be designed in Australia specifically for defence purposes and the first local design project since the civil-military Nomad.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement concerning the new River Murray Waters Agreement and to move a motion that the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the text of the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
NEW RIVER MURRAY WATERS AGREEMENT

I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia have endorsed a draft of a new River Murray Waters Agreement. This was the outcome of a meeting which the Prime Minister and I attended last Friday in Melbourne, together with the three respective Premiers and their water resources Ministers.

The Prime Minister and Premiers have agreed that the draft new Agreement now be referred to the Crown Law advisers of the four governments with a view to the early introduction of the necessary legislation. In the meantime, the River Murray Commission has been authorised to operate fully within the terms of the new Agreement, pending completion of the necessary legislative action.

The draft new Agreement is the result of the first major review of the Agreement signed in 1914. It is now proposed to expand the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission to include water quality in addition to the responsibilities it now has for water quantity in the main stem of the river and associated storages. At the same time, the Agreement is being updated to make it more relevant to present day requirements by giving the River Murray Commission responsibilities in regard to other water management objectives.

Under the proposed new Agreement, the River Murray Commission will be authorised to formulate river water quality objectives or standards, as appropriate, for various locations on the river. State authorities will be required to inform the Commission of all proposals under their consideration which could significantly affect water quality and quantity in the river and provide the necessary information to permit an assessment of their likely impact. Obviously, the agreed water quality objectives will be of central relevance to such an assessment. The Commission will be empowered to make representations as necessary to the appropriate State authority on such proposals.

Further, the water distribution provisions of the new Agreement will enable account to be taken of the quality of the inflows of tributaries and man-made outfalls in assessing the credits of the States in the Commission's water accounting procedures. Rules are to be drawn up for this purpose.

As in every river system, water quality in the River Murray is the end product of numerous activities which take place in the catchment-in irrigation, dryland agriculture, processing industries, urban centres, forestry, et cetera. These are all State responsibilities. There is no intention of the River Murray Commission having a regulatory function, the power of sanctions in regard to these matters or the right to interfere in the States' affairs. The new arrangements aim at a joint assessment of all relevant water and land use and other factors significantly affecting water quality. This is consistent with the development of river management strategies where a river and its catchment fall within the responsibility of a single government.

While in this regard the River Murray Commission will have only the power of persuasion, its representations will be based on mutually agreed water quality objectives or standards, and on an ever increasing body of knowledge of the river system and its problems.

Subject to the new water quality provisions, the current water sharing principles and arrangements between the three States will continue. South Australia will be entitled to 1.85 million megalitres annually as measured at the South Australian border in accordance with specified monthly volumes. This includes the recent 23 per cent increase made possible by the completion of Dartmouth Dam. The two upper States will share the balance of the water resources available to the River Murray Commission, but with some flexibility to cope with year-to-year pressures in water demands.

While the River Murray Waters Agreement is, and will continue to remain, the main policy instrument for the Commonwealth's involvement with the three States in the management of the nation's most important water resource, considerable financial assistance has been provided to the three States for those salinity control and drainage works in the Murray Valley which fall outside the area of the Commission's responsibilities. These are all priority works recommended by Consulting Engineers, Maunsell and Partners, in the plan of action they proposed in their 1979 report on salinity and drainage problems in the Murray Valley.

By the end of this financial year, we will have provided about $18 million in grants to the cost of underground and surface saline water drainage works on a $ for $ basis with the three States-a total of $36 million. Together, we are well advanced in the implementation of urgent works identified in the Maunsell plan of action.

It is the view of this government that, before any decisions are contemplated regarding a follow-up to the implementation of the plan of action, time must be allowed for the accumulation and assessment of vital information arising from the three important recent joint Commonwealth/States initiatives. We need to know the effectiveness of the new water quality responsibilities now proposed for the River Murray Commission, the full operational impact of Dartmouth Dam and the efficiency of salinity control projects already completed, or under construction. Subject to this review, we will give careful consideration to new salinity control projects in accordance with priorities identified by the States in conjunction with the River Murray Commission.

Basic data for this purpose is already being gathered. The Commission has now established a water quality monitoring network along the river to record salinity and other key parameters and consultants are being engaged shortly to develop a mathematical computer model to simulate the operation of the river system, not only in terms of river flows and storage changes, but also in terms of river water quality. This model should be an invaluable instrument in the development and operation of long-term strategies to reduce salinity in the river system to manageable proportions, and all efforts are being made to ensure its early completion.

There are already signs that recent initiatives by the four governments are gradually becoming effective. Water quality recordings by the River Murray Commission during last season's severe drought indicated that salinity levels were lower than in previous comparable dry periods. This comparative improvement has been attributed to the initial operations of Dartmouth Dam-now about two-thirds full-and the effectiveness of already completed salinity control works. High river flows resulting from heavy winter rains and snow-melt are having a very beneficial flushing effect on the river system, and adequate water supplies of good quality should be available next season.

It is recognised throughout the world where irrigation has induced salinity problems, that techniques which reduce the application of water surplus to plant requirements are essential to the success of any long-term strategy to bring the problem under control. Amendments in May and December 1980 to the Income Tax Assessment Act now provide strong incentives to irrigators to improve their watering practices. The new provisions of the Act allow full deductibility of expenditures for income tax assessment purposes on water conservation and conveyance, salinity control and associated drainage works in the same year as they are incurred. We understand that these incentives are now starting to become effective.

However, a better definition of the magnitude of the problem is required, and the four governments agreed last Friday that a Commonwealth/States working group should review the extent to which irrigators are adopting improved irrigation practices and assess the possible need for additional incentives. It is clear that without complementary preventative measures at the farm level, initiatives by the four governments in the fight against salinity will be impaired.

The Government is mindful of South Australia's specific problems with River Murray water quality-particularly during prolonged periods of minimum river flow conditions. To some extent, these problems originate outside the State. In relation to drinking water, there is the additional problem of turbidity caused by the presence of suspended soil particles and organic material, which reflect run-off conditions in the vast catchment including parts of Queensland. Commonwealth financial assistance, already reaching $40 million, is enabling South Australia to build a water filtration scheme for metropolitan Adelaide. Two filtration installations are already operational. The scheme, when completed, will contribute significantly to an improvement in the colour and taste of drinking water from the Murray integrated into Adelaide's water supplies.

The River Murray Waters Agreement has worked to the advantage of all three States for over 60 years. Admittedly, managing the river for water quantity is far less demanding than taking account also of water quality, having regard particularly to the constitutional role of the States in practically all aspects of water and land use which affect river water quality. We do not underestimate the difficulties and complex issues which lie ahead. But with goodwill on the part of all concerned and a determination to make the proposed new River Murray Waters Agreement work, the long-term environmental health of the river and the economic well-being of the numerous urban centres and vast irrigation settlements in the Murray Valley can be assured.

Perhaps some of the problem has been alleviated by heavy rainfall this winter in the catchment areas. It still remains a cause of continuing concern that the administration of a national resource and the planning for the development of such a national resource should be in the hands of what is perhaps a weak body where State representatives appear as State representatives.

The task in connection with the use of the Murray will require engineering, economic and scientific competence and probably some diplomatic skill. In time a task force of the nature of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority may be required to grapple adequately with the problems which cover those broad areas of engineering, economic expertise and scientific competence and to ensure that the parties to the Agreement are not, as it were, State representatives but are genuinely concerned with the administration of a national resource. One would hope that, arising from the Agreement, some attempt would be made to formulate time scales for achieving the quality standards to which the statement refers. The injection of the notion of quality standards is something, as I said, which is very much to be commended but, if those quality standards are not subject to time scales for achievement, there may be little satisfaction with the way in which the problem is being handled.

Some time ago, the Opposition proposed in the House of Representatives-a private member's Bill has been introduced into the Senate for the same purpose-the establishment of an Institute of Freshwater Studies. In a continent the size of Australia, with water having been a recognised national problem for a very long time, we think it is high time that the expertise which is available to this country in the various disciplines which I have mentioned be brought together in a cross-disciplinary way to tackle on a national level the problems of the provision of an adequate supply of fresh water and the question of water quality. This would appropriately be done in such an institute. We believe this is still needed and we will be proceeding with a private member's Bill in relation to the establishment of such an institute. At the appropriate time we will be commending it to the Senate.
