TALK.START.PARA: —As a South Australian, it is something of a compulsion for me to make a few comments about any report, any piece of legislation or anything at all that comes into the Senate in regard to the River Murray. Unfortunately, I do not think that my comments on the new River Murray Waters Agreement will be nearly as laudatory as those of Senator Button. In fact, most of what I have to say will not approve at all of this statement. Before I make the comments, I stress that I hope that what I say will be proved wrong not just in the long term but also in the short term. Nevertheless, the points have to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The new River Murray Waters Agreement is the result of a meeting between the Commonwealth Government and the governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia; that is, between the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Premiers of those three States. We have in the Federal sphere and in Victoria and South Australia Liberal governments, at least for the time being, and again at least for the time being in New South Wales a Labor Government is in office. It seems fairly incredible to a rather cynical soul like me that three States of different political persuasions and a Federal government could have come so quickly to an agreement on a water source which has been, far from the source of water for South Australia, the source of disagreement between those States and the Commonwealth for a great many years.

From a close look at the statement, it is hardly surprising that those three State Premiers and the Prime Minister of Australia were able to come to such an apparently amicable agreement. The fact is that there are no teeth in this Agreement at all. The statement points out in paragraph three on page one that the new draft is the first major review of the Agreement since 1914. That, in itself, is an indictment of State and Federal government attitudes to the problem. It should have come to some sort of review a lot sooner than this. I can recall saying as long ago as 1978 that South Australia's water required chewing 32 times before being swallowed. Senator Macklin can smirk but his State does not have the sort of water that we have. It is not even opaque.

This statement recommends that the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission be expanded to incorporate water quality as well as water quantity. This was a subject that was hardly likely to interest our founding fathers or the people who were looking at the problems of water distribution from the Murray in 1914 since quality was not even considered to be a matter warranting any sort of legislation. Neither the population nor the sort of water usage at the time warranted it and certainly the technology of the day did not presage the sorts of events and usage that we now have. So it is good to see the statement incorporates into the Agreement what it terms as present day requirements by giving the River Murray Commission responsibility in regard to water management objectives other than simply quantity.

It will formulate river water quality objectives or standards, as appropriate, for particular locations on the river. So it should because I contend that what South Australia has had to put up with over the last couple of decades is nothing short of water piracy. Page 2 of the statement says that the Commission will be empowered to make representations as necessary to the appropriate State authority on the proposals mentioned earlier in that paragraph. One's first thought when reading that is to ask 'Will they be binding?' The answer to the question comes two paragraphs further on where, having pointed out that numerous activities are taking place in water catchment areas-irrigation, dryland agriculture, processing industries, et cetera-the statement blandly and calmly states:
There is no intention of the River Murray Commission having a regulatory function, the power of sanctions in regard to these matters or the right to interfere in the State's affairs.

It is nothing more than a toothless tiger whose only power is in the power of persuasion. Its representations will be based on 'mutually agreed water quality objectives or standards'. I ask: How on earth can anybody expect State and Federal governments with different aims, different ambitions and different political colourings to come to any sort of mutual agreement, much less over their major waterway? It is hardly likely that one State government will voluntarily agree to a politically unpopular move-for instance, a measure to limit irrigation licences or other sorts of water restrictions-simply to adopt what Senator Evans persists in calling a spirit of co-operation and friendship with another State government of a different political persuasion. It would be political suicide.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they agreed on quantity before, why can they not agree now on quality?
—Simply because it is politically unwise for them to do that.
—But that argument applies to quantities, and they agreed on quantities.

—In 1914 politics were slightly more gentlemanly than they are today. Any increase in water for South Australia is absolutely useless if the commodity is not potable; if it is in effect not only not drinkable but also not usable for agriculture and irrigation purposes. The only solutions that this statement puts forward, and I commend it for at least doing something, are short term, wrong-ended ones. At the moment it is being forced to look at the situation and provide some sort of financial assistance for salinity control and drainage works in the Murray Valley. That, of course, is commendable. It is, unfortunately, not a solution to the problem but a cure of something. The two are not necessarily synonymous, particularly where the River Murray is concerned. If they are not wrong-end solutions or attempts to mend fences, they are long term ones. On page 4 the statement says that time must be allowed. I emphasise the word 'time'. I just wonder how much longer South Australia must wait for time to be allowed for things to be sorted out, for vital information to be accumulated and assessed, before we get some sort of concrete solution. Perhaps I should not use the word 'concrete', given the magnitude of the pollution of the river at the moment. The statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to know the effectiveness of the new water quality responsibilities now proposed for the River Murray Commission, the full operational impact of the Dartmouth Dam and the efficiency of salinity control . . .

My contention is that we need to do and to know more than that. We need to know that there will be genuine co-operation between governments, genuine concern not just for their own short term political benefits but for the general welfare of the State at the wrong end of this river. At the moment we are being forced to depend on climatic good luck. On page 5 the statement makes the point that we are very fortunate that, despite last season's severe drought, the salinity levels at the moment are lower than those in previous comparable dry periods and that there is expected to be a very beneficial flushing effect due to the heavy winter rains, and so on. But those are fortuitous circumstances, unless somebody is going to try to tell us that at last governments control the weather.

On page 6 the statement points out that some attempts have been made to offset the damage being done to the river's quality by irrigation because in May and December 1980 amendments were made to the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide incentives to irrigators. This is terrific news. But it is not enough to have an incentive such as that simply to offset another abuse. Finally, at the bottom of page 6, South Australia rates a particular mention, being the recipient of the thin edge of the wedge. The statement states:

The Government is mindful of South Australia's specific problems with River Murray water quality-particularly during prolonged periods of minimum river flow conditions. To some extent, these problems originate outside the State.

I know a large number of people in South Australia's Riverland who would attribute all of the problems in the water that gets to them as originating outside the State. Certainly it gets worse as it goes on. The fact of the matter is that we have fruit trees dying off, we have people becoming bankrupt, and most South Australians are unable to drink the water simply because of what starts before the water even gets to our border. A more incredible statement, however, appears on page 7 of the statement. It reads:
The River Murray Waters Agreement has worked to the advantage of all three States for over 60 years.

I am wondering which three States it is concerned about here. The RMWA has not worked to the advantage of South Australia in the past 60 years, certainly not over the past decade. We have had most appalling water in South Australia for as long as I can remember and it has been, to a certain extent, because the agreement has never had incorporated in it the element of quality control. The statement continues:
We do not underestimate the difficulties and complex issues which lie ahead.
That somewhat understates the matter-

But with goodwill on the part of all concerned and a determination to make the proposed new River Murray Waters Agreement work, the long-term environmental health of the river and the economic well-being of the numerous urban centres and vast irrigation settlements in the Murray Valley can be assured.

I do not think we will get that goodwill. I do not think it will come from this statement although, as I said at the beginning of my speech, I hope more than anything for which I have hoped for a long time that my comments on this matter will be proven wrong. To me this statement is little more than a series of pious platitudes. It does nothing to ensure that the upstream States give South Australia good quality water as of right. It does nothing to move in the short term for an improvement, certainly not for a drastic improvement, in the quality of a waterway which is rapidly approaching roadway status. It makes some attempt to solve the problem at the wrong end of the river by providing funds for salination control and so on. For that I do give it credit. Nevertheless, as far as South Australia is concerned, I am unable to do anything else but reject and resent the rather glib long-term solution proffered in this statement.

The problems of the River Murray can never be solved, as I am sure you are aware, Mr President, by a gentlemen's agreement in a political situation in Australia in which gentlemen's agreements no longer apply. There is no longer any place for them in Australian politics. It seems to me that this is a grandstanding exercise on behalf of all three State governments and the Prime Minister. I hope I am not being excessively harsh in saying that. They are going to be able to get up and claim kudos for endorsing this Agreement. The resulting headlines will, I daresay, do each of them some good and I guess that will achieve their short term aims. But it will not do anything in the short term that is positive for South Australia's water. The last paragraph on page 2 of this statement makes this perfectly clear. Unless and until some more positive solution is found, South Australia will continue to suffer from the selfishness and the thoughtlessness of actions in other States. I would have thought that more positive action could come through the Prime Minister's much vaunted co-operative federalism scheme. The States concerned could voluntarily relinquish to the Federal Government their powers over the River Murray.

It saw the election of a new government, but a government that was very much a right wing government, aligned with once again and propped up by the security forces. At that 1974 election the New Democracy Party of the then Prime Minister Karamanlis polled over 54 per cent of the vote. That election also saw the birth of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement-the PASOK party. In 1974 that party polled 13.6 per cent of the vote. The emergence of PASOK has continued since 1974 and in the 1977 election it almost doubled its vote to about 26 per cent. At that election the vote of the New Democracy Party fell. However, it managed to maintain sufficient seats in the 300-member parliament to retain government.

The election of 18 October, just three days ago, saw once again a doubling of the vote for PASOK-a vote which now stands somewhere in the vicinity of 48 per cent. At the same time the Moscow aligned Communist Party has managed to maintain and increase its vote. All in all, the election of two days ago has meant a clear mandate for reform and radical changes in Greece. It has ensured for the first time in recent Greek history that a left wing socialist government has an absolute majority of seats in the Greek Parliament. PASOK now has 175 seats out of 300 seats and can govern in its own right. The main proponent of PASOK, the person who gave PASOK birth, was Andreas Papandreou. At the moment he is 62 years of age and he has been involved to a large extent in recent Greek history. He is a doctor of economics. He has in fact instructed at the Harvard School of Economics. His involvement in Greek economics has included both Guggenheim and Fulbright fellowships. He was also asked in 1964 to establish a Greek centre for economic research. He has an adequate and quite good knowledge of the Greek economic system.

In 1964 he stood for a seat in parliament. He in fact won a seat as a member of the Greek Centre Union Government, a government in which his father was Prime Minister and in which he was a prominent member and a prominent Minister. That Government did not last long. In fact, the first coup to befall Greece in the 1960s came in 1965 when the King deposed the democratically elected government, a government which had been elected with the support of 53 per cent of the Greek people, and replaced it with puppet governments for almost two years. In the middle of 1967, when an election was to be called again and when the Papandreou Centre Union Party was expected to be returned to government, another coup occurred. The election was not held until 1974. Papandreou suffered at the time of that coup. He was arrested and held in solitary confinement for eight months. At the end of that period he was given amnesty on the basis that he leave Greece and stay out of Greece. He said at the time:
For America-
The coup-
represents a dangerous experiment in foreign policy, consisting of the extension of its Latin American policy to the shores of Europe.

It is this theme that he has continued amongst other themes in pursuance of the independence of Greece. He recognised that the obsequious nature of Greek governments since 1967 meant that the Greek people had not been able to realise their true worth and independence.

The implications of the election of the present Greek government are wide and many, not only for Europe and for the Greek people themselves but also for the world. This government is the second government of a European Economic Community country in six months to be elected on a vote against conservatism and a vote in favour of democratic radical socialism. This election and the election of Francois Mitterrand in France can be tied in with the growth of a popular movement throughout Europe at the moment which is well portrayed in disarmament rallies and anti-nuclear campaigns. In fact, it represents a move throughout Europe, and I would suggest a move that will be carried on throughout the rest of the world, for a radical reorganisation of the world system.

The vote of the Greek people meant a number of things. It was a vote for a new economic and social order for Greece; it was in fact a vote against the current transnational domination of that country and the economic repression that comes with that. It was a vote against inequality and it was a vote against external domination. In fact, it was a vote for independence, for a better share of wealth and for a better quality of life for the Greek people. The Greek people ought to be commended for their perception and their strength in taking their convictions to a vote.

The Papandreou victory means a number of things. For the Greeks in Greece it means, as the now Prime Minister mentioned throughout his campaign, a reorganisation and a restructuring of the Greek economy. It means regionalisation of both administration and power. It means socialisation. Papandreou has always said that to him socialisation means that Greek people should benefit by both control and profit sharing from the most basic and profitable areas of Greek industry and that this includes areas such as energy, transport, banks, ship building, chemicals, fertilisers and cement. The most profitable areas of Greek industry should, under the PASOK Government, accrue benefits to the Greek people and not their foreign masters. It also means-and this is one of the most underrated areas of his policy-a revision of the role of women in Greek society. The PASOK Government has promised equal pay, anti-discrimination legislation and state provided child care facilities. This will bring about a radical reorganisation and a radical restructure in the role of women in the Greek community.

He also promises a dissociation of both church and state, something which I believe is to be welcomed and which can only be in the best interests of Greek people. He also promises worker involvement, wage indexation and a number of social welfare reforms, including universal medical care and pension reform. If one studies the rise of Papandreou, one can see that all of those policies were tenets of his when he was last in government in 1967. He has maintained his themes, he has maintained his beliefs and he has developed on them. Over a period he has managed to sell them to an electorate which has now shown that it was quite willing to accept them.

I believe that the experience of Papandreou in 1964, 1965, 1967 and thereafter is shown more and more in the field of foreign policy. During that period he realised that Greece could no longer continue to be a servant of the United States and that it had to stand up for itself. That type of theme comes out time and time again in respect of the PASOK policies which have been endorsed and accepted by the Greek people. PASOK has promised to review Greece's involvement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. The Prime Minister of Greece has promised that this review will involve a rejection of military involvement with NATO but a reassessment of the continuation of political involvement with NATO. It is obvious that the Prime Minister will now make Greece stand up and use its independent status, its realigned status, in the interests of the Greek people and the Greek Cypriot people and not in the interests of foreign powers.

His attitude in respect of United States bases is one which I think we in Australia should look at with interest. His experience between 1964 and 1967 showed him that the Central Intelligence Agency could not be trusted and its involvement in the Greek community and society could not be tolerated. His policy in respect of United States bases now is that they be withdrawn over time but that in the meantime, as he asserted time and time again during the campaign, the role of the bases should be de-Americanised, as he put it, and over the short term renegotiated to ensure that Greece controls in the interim the operation of the bases.

During the campaign he also declared that there would be no nuclear weapons on Greek soil. We also know that it is proposed to hold a referendum of Greek people on the renegotiation of continued EEC involvement. As I said, the PASOK policy for Greece promises an independent nation that can stand in world affairs as a non-aligned country. Papandreou is not going into government this time without experience. I mentioned earlier some aspects of his experience. He has been involved in three coups of one sort or another. In 1961 falsification of election results by the then Prime Minister Karamanlis ensured that the Government of George Papandreou was rejected by the people. As I said earlier, there was a coup in 1965 from King Constantine and once again in 1967 there was a coup. Papandreou comes into government having lived through that recent history of Greece and having suffered from it. He knows that there are no soft options for him.

I finish my speech by referring to a couple of quotations from his book Democracy at Gunpoint which was published in 1971 and which in many ways laid the groundwork for his campaign over the last 10 years. He said:

We placed many hopes, much too many, on the possibility of mobilising the private sector of the economy to perform its developmental role . . . but we failed to understand that it was not enough to create a climate of opportunity for investment and set up a system of incentives.

He knows that and his intervention in the economy is a response to that. He went on to say as a matter of tactics that the then Government's much milder, less demanding, less radical development program, which had been intended to prevent the alienation of the Establishment, created no less hostility. He said:
That any reform was poison to them-we might just as well have gone further and formulated a plan of action that would have made a difference for Greece.

It is that difference that he has now had the Greek people accept. He now has a mandate from the Greek people. The last quote I put on record from the same book-I think it sums up the future of Greece under Papandreou-is:
The struggle for a free Greece will continue until victory comes. And then Greece will move forward to take its place in Europe as a free, democratic, sovereign nation.
Once again I congratulate the new Prime Minister of Greece, Mr Andreas Papandreou.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two speakers in the adjournment debate tonight. I listened with interest to Senator Bolkus's eulogy on the new Greek Government. I hope he passes copies of his speech on to the new Prime Minister. I am sure he will be interested.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to respond to Senator Mulvihill's comments in which he asked a number of questions to which I think answers are required. I start by saying that I am not aware of the intricacies of demarcation problems that may arise. I think the honourable senator referred to some of those as possibilities in relation to the watchmen on whom he and I as early birds or late birds in that building in Sydney depend so much. But I do agree there is a need for adequate arrangements to protect them.

I remind the Senate that the Government decision to transfer the cleaning and watching function of the Department of Administrative Services to the private sector was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions on 30 April last. It reflects the view of the Government that certain services presently provided by the Government could be more effectively provided by the private sector. The honourable senator was not questioning that view. He was questioning the kinds of arrangements that might be made and protection for some of the people whom he knows and who have worked there.

Guidelines for the arrangements for staff affected by such transfers do envisage staff being offered employment by the contractors taking over the function, to the maximum extent possible. That is envisaged in the arrangements which are provided. The staff who are offered employment will receive benefits normally applying on retrenchment because that is another aspect of their protection that has to be looked at.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about employment with the new employer. You are not talking about the obligations of the Commonwealth to make severance payments.

—I have not come to that. If a new contractor comes in, it is hoped that the present employees would be taken up to the maximum extent possible. When that happens, they will require benefits applying on retrenchment when they change from one employment to another. The staff not offered employment with the contractor or the staff who choose not to take up an offer will have the protection of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act and they will have the protection of associated arbitral determinations which are administered by the Public Service Board. These arrangements and the decision to effect the transfer next month were conveyed to the staff concerned by officers of the Department of Administrative Services last week, on 12 October 1981. The Department at the present time is in discussion with contractors interested in tendering for the cleaning and watching of Commonwealth properties and its expectation is that they will engage existing staff if they do take over that function.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other points were raised by Senator Mulvihill, particularly points relating to possible conflicts between people doing different functions for the same firms, which I will pass on to the relevant Minister. I finish my remarks by observing that at least one of the watchmen whom we both knew well over the years, Mr Bill Burgess, who looked after us both for many years, made the transfer at one stage from the Commonwealth service to work for Pritchard Security Services and at least he survived the change. We continue to see him around quite often still doing the watchman's function. I believe the change can be made. I would hope that the talks which are presently in progress can be brought to a successfull conclusion and that the concerns which have been expressed by Senator Mulvihill can be met adequately.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.56 p.m.
